content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												After playing it a bit more, I've decided to change my opinion a bit. I still recommend the title, but there are caveats. Lots of them. The game has good parts and ... very awkward parts.Good: Voxel creation tool. It is absolutely amazing. Editor is well designed, and this how in-game object design should be done.Awkward:Oh, boy... there's a lot of those.Enemies are bullet sponges. Not just a normal bullet sponges, but supreme bullet sponges. Every fight is equivalent to fighting M1 Abrams tank using bb gun. Except that driver of m1 is drunk or asleep and for some reason has hard time overrunning or hitting you. You plink everything to death, even with very tough weapons. Especially on foot.  Judging by in-game comments (left by NPCs) they were turned into bullet sponges on purpose, to demonstrate "how tough" the planet is.Combat in general. All enemy movements is strange. Creatures have very hard time hitting you, and you have very hard time moving around with a ranged weapon. For some reason it uses MMO game structures. Meaning you have a lot of fairly useless npcs with floating "!" and "?" over their head. Haven't seen this since playing HellGate: London.Voice acting. The studio tried to introduce voice acting, BUT it is quite hammy at times. Some npcs are alright, but intro would work much better without voice.Design vs Utility. There's something very strange going on with armor and weapon designs. Basically, due to amazing editor, you can design any gun. Except its stats will suck compared to in-game generic bullet rifle. Apparently in the past it was possible to make weapons with multiple barrels, or with barrel pointing in different direction, and then this ability was for some reason removed. Which is a pity. There's not much point in designing your own gun, unless you go after specific look. Armor design process has similar problem. You can make a breastplate out of diamond, and its defence rating will be very low.Designing wearable armor is also awkward. Unlike vehicle/gun design tool, which works flawlessly, the armor design tool has trouble remembering to which body part it is supposed to be attached, and to which gender it is designed. So, if you design a "belt" part of armor, and try to equip it, the game will stick it into your character's chest instead. Armor must be equipped in specific order, apparently. Also, designed armor doesn't even go into slot you specify. It is on separate page, and you're apparently supposed to manually adjust placcement of individual items. So, this functionality looks unfinished.Audio issues. Audio that is being played in your spekaers is calculated relative to character's head. Even if you play using third person camera. meaning if your character looks at the camera and something explodes to character's right, you'll hear sound coming from left instead. Strange that this bug exists (it is easily fixable)Bringing an item from creator into the world is awkward too. You see, in the game you find "scripts", which allow you to make items with replicator (as long as you have resources). So one would assume that making something in editor would produce similar "script".. but NOPE. For some reason, this is done very differently - you're supposed to have parts of model in inventory, and instead of using a script, you need to go into model editor mode and "export" the model.Resource trees aren't properly automated. Let's say you need to create item X, that requires components A, B, C whiere A requires D, E F, B requires D, G, H and C requires D G F. You can't just click on final product and order the game to automatically create missing components for every level. Instead you need go through individual components and create them manually. Very annoying.The whole colony management thing is, frankly, weird and feels out of place. Everything about it is very poorly explained, and making a colony turns the game into tower defense. Also, you can apparently bring "story" npcs into your colony, even if they're givers for main story quests. I'm not sure if this even supposed to be possible.I still think the game is decent, in the sense that roaming part of it is fun, and voxel creator is very cool. However there are a lot of weirdness and strange design choices going on, and the game feels very rough around edges. It looks a bit dated by now too.So, it is worth checking out, but it definitely doesn't reach its full potential.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												This will be my first review on steam, but I shall do my best anyway.This game is an interesting answer to a gripe fans of the Build/Survival genre for a long time. Most games of this nature are rarely unique and often feel like digital cut-outs of something like Minecraft (which in its self is virtual Legos), but Planet Explorers feels different. Not only is Planet Explorers different, but it feels as if the creators genuinely cared for the title they were working on. The game uses a system for creation that feels a bit like it may have been used by the developers themselves, when a Planet Explorer player says that you can build or create anything they mean it (you have been warned).Now that does not mean it does not have problems.- The graphics are not all that impressive 7/10- The sound needs some serious work 4/10- The procedural generation has many many flaws -/-- The worst of all are the controls 2/10The controls are seriously in need of work. There are three control schemes; the first being similar to many MMOs with the mouse cursor having free movement across the screen and requiring the right mouse button to move the camera, the second is an awkward version of the first with the cursor locked and mouse movement directly translating to camera movement, and the third is a wonky hard to use first person camera. In my honest opinion this game would have done well with a simple over the shoulder third person shooter camera angle. In conclusion the game is very fun for the niche gamer, but without a proper control scheme it will not hold much appeal for the average gamer (and many Build/Survival players as well).

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't even know where to start.  As others have said, this game is exactly what I've sought for a long time.  In a nutshell, they managed to take the positive aspects of various sandbox crafting games and made it fun and removed the tendency to become boring.I love this game and can't stop playing it.  I can't say the concept of the game is simple because there are so many directions it can go.  There isn't a clear direction on the devs' part, and I mean that in a good way.  They've built a really solid foundation and I'm hanging on the edge of my seat waiting for the next update.I came across this game looking for something that gives me open-world exploration and crafting.  This game delivers that and then some.  Easily one of the best games I have in my library.It is tempting to try to compare this to games like Minecraft, Starbound, Terraria, etc., and it wouldn't be wrong to do so: there are a lot of similarities, and feels like some of the devs either worked on one of those or took a lot of inspiration from them, but then again many of these aren't really new concepts.  And in my opinion there's nothing wrong with borrowing ideas that work.Where this game really delivers is graphics -- the lack of good graphics made the aforementioned games quickly boring for me;  the Creation Editor, where you can build fairly detailed models from base materials and attach crafted assets to make fairly complicated structures such as custom weapons, vehicles (land, air, AND sea), etc. -- the CE really is a game within a game and I've spent a good chunk of time just creating things there;  and the beginnings of a pretty nice "town management" system; you craft the various components of your village, invite npcs to live with you, and assign various tasks. not a lot to it right now but it has the makings of a really fun mini-game... and that's all above and beyond (what i find to be the very zen-like process of) mining and scavenging raw materials to build with, and doing actual exploration.  The time in-game shown as of right now (just over 38 hours) is how long it took me to get through the "story" part of the game, and several quests are incomplete, so it just goes to show that they intend to do more with that part of it.  As expected, there are plenty of bugs to work out, but the game is so engaging I barely notice them, except for the ones that break quests at which point i have to reload from a last save or something, but overall the game is amazingly well done given it's still in alpha.This game easily gets a 10/10.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Since I bought the game I have been playing it for 4 days straight and not even stick of truth was able to keep me engaged so much. This game is basically Minecraft plus with better graphics (compared to other Minecraft-ish games), better mobs (from the cute little woodland critter to giant dinosaur roaming the plain), somewhat better crafting (you can craft modern tools and equipment) and a better story (does Minecraft even have a story except killing the dragon?) Of course there are many aspects that are not on par with Minecraft such as water/lava physics, processing items on other items (putting meat on fire to cook) etc. but we shall see how the final edition will be.Pros:1. Best graphics among Minecraft-ish games so far (DON'T YOU EVER COMPARE THIS TO CALL OF DUTY. I AM SICK OF STUPID COMPARISON. CAN YOU DIG YOURSELF A KHAZAD DUM IN CALL OF DUTY?)2. Somewhat cool story (as a Black Isle worshiper, I can't say I am impressed but the story is at least solid)3. The world and the atmosphere are awesome. It does give you a feeling of adventuring in an unknown planet with cool (sometimes crazy looking) creatures and weird plants and landscape and ancient ruins.4. The ability to drive land vehicles and fly helicopters and construct missile launcher/laser cannon etc. 5. The ISO system is fascinating. You can literally create anything you can ever imagine.6. JET PACK AND GLIDER! seriously, try it out. get to the top of a mountain, run, fire your jet pack, switch to glider at max height and enjoy ;)7. other minor pros listed by other reviewersCons:some technical issues1. memory leak crash. It seems quite some people have this problem and I encountered it a few times in the game as well. luckily it does not seem to happen too frequently (for me) and the game autosave every 10 minutes so you won't lose much.2. lag? not really a con but the game somehow confuses people by including an option in the launcher where you can choose video card. THIS IS NOT WHERE YOU CHOOSE GPU FOR THE GAME. if you are using Nvidia card you have to manually set the game (PE_client) to use your gaming GPU in Nvidia control panel or I guarantee you that your game will lag as cr*p.3. possible problem with fast travel and sleeping and saving at meteor crate. Some players report bugs that delete all your autosave files when they fast travel from meteor crate and sometimes it involves them sleeping or saving at that location. Personally I didn't encounter any problem but just to put it out here.4. if you delete your steam and then reinstall steam and play the game using your old save (the same version)... you may see some empty texture in places where you dug. when you jump through the empty texture you will somehow reappear in the sky...5. I somehow encounter a bug where if you put a roof closely on top of your defense cannons. they will magically appear on top of the roof...6. multiplayer is still quite buggy so don't expect too much fun from theregameplay issues:0. NEED CHANGE ASAP - monster corpses disappear too fast. when you are fighting a pack of monsters, before you can finish the last one, the other corpses may start dissolving already. it is like you have less than 1 min to pick up the loot and it is not cool.1. NPC SELLS TOO MANY STUFF. you can literally buy everything from NPC with meat. In multiplayer you can even access this one global shop where everything is on sale. I think it is better that only the uncraftable/uncollectible items and some basic starting tools are purchasable. 2. combat still needs a bit of work. 3. can't dig and move at the same time. when you start digging you are rooted.4. monsters are not very threatening, except that black crab thing. don't know why but black crab can sometimes one hit kill you.5. can't use weapon while flying with glider (imagine how cool it can be when you rain death from above :D)6. the bottom of the lake/ocean is always flicking... also the color of your vehicle will be changing randomly if you alt+tab out and get back in the game7. many objects are not solid, for example, trees. only a small part of a huge tree is solid so you can walk through a tree and fly through a tree but sometimes you can't because that part of the tree decides it wants to be solid and you hit the tree and crash :(8. the mineral scanner does not seem to work properly when you are moving so you are forced to stand still in order to scan. 9. unlike in MC where you craft items by placing materials in specific ways, this game uses crafting scripts and the crafting script list can be a bit overwhelming later when you collect a lot of them or when you play multiplayer where you are given all scripts at the beginning. although you can search them by types it is still not very convenient. In summary, a cool game that is still at alpha with alpha problems but definitely playable and just look at the cool features the devs are planning so if you like Minecraft-ish games then try this out. You can't be disappointed, unless you are that kind of player who likes hand holding all the time then why are you playing a Minecraft-ish game in the first place?

Early Access Review
								This was a promising game, back in the days. The recent update contains enough bugs to completely ruin any game. Collision detection is completely random (this means that there's a good probability of you getting stuck in the air), the controls are awful (some can't even be remapped, because for instance, the tab key doesn't want to be recognised, despite already being mapped), and the AI is one of the worst I have ever had the misfortune of play with\against. I'm sad to say that in the current state, it's not even worth a quarter of what they charge for it. MAYBE one day, when all the bugs are fixed, it will be worth it, but this is not that day.Edit 29th of May: One of three gamebreaking bugs is fixed - AI no longer terrible. Two more to go, and the thumbs down becomes thumbs up.

Posted: March 11
												Great game, overall I found myself impressed with the scope and diveristy of gamelplay. The game appears to be quite polished and the graphics are pretty lovely as well.The creative system in itself is probably already worth giving this game a 5/5 stars. I had a lot of fun just playing with the creation system, making several creations and testing them out inside the game. Probably the most solid boxel design system I've seen so far.The combat is fun and engaging, some of the enemies are pretty tough, which in turn made powering up feel very rewarding. Defeating foes which I struggled with in the past was very pleasant.The characters are very well written and the story so far is looking great too.The exploration is amazing, probably the best component of the game, scouting the unknown alien planet felt very engaging. That being said, I did not love the mineral prospecting system. as valuable resources were scattered too thinly and searching for them was not incredibly enjoyable.That being said I give this game a 5/5. It is incredible that I could get such a great game for such a nice price. Thoroughly recommended.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								As expected, Planet Explorers is a work in progress, and aside from the bugs, what's there could easily be a stand-alone game.  The number of hours of playtime I have enjoyed is staggering when compared to most AAA titles, so I consider it money well spent.That said, the game is very rough around the edges, so if you are the type to get frustrated easily by bugs, glitches, and terrible ally pathfinding, you might want to give the game some time to mature.  I lost count of how many times I arrived at a quest destination after a long journey, only to realize that the quest NPC(s) was nowhere to be found.  Most of the time, retracing my steps would lead me to said NPC(s) running mindlessly into a tree or rock, which I would have to destroy to snap them out of their strange trance.  Occasionally, they would get stuck on nothing.  Occasionally, I would get stuck on nothing, too.  This is just the tip of the iceberg.But if you can tolerate typical early access issues during early access, I think you will find the story is quite atypical--in a good way--for this sort of game, and the city building is shaping up to be something special.  It isn't quite there yet, but Planet Explorers has tons of quests, tons of dialog, and tons of ways to utilize and/or manage your colony.  The voxel system itself is pretty flexible, and once you get used to it (which does take some time) the in-game editor is surprisingly easy to use.  You can make decorations, equipments, and even vehicles.UPDATE 4/29/2016Quite some time has passed, and that time has not been kind to this title.  It is nearly as clumsy as it ever was, and other Early Access games have since been released in a worse state only to progress leaps and bounds beyond Planet Explorers.  I am not yet ready to change my recommendation to a "No", but I am close.  I suspect I will have to, at some point.  For now, if this is your niche, I still cautiously recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 6
Product received for free
Planet ExplorersPlanet Explorers is a game about exploring alien hostile lands while trying to survive and build your own kingdom. Does it make the exploration worthwhile or shoots itself in the head, let’s find out:Gameplay:Planet Explorers contains 3 game modes: Story mode, Adventure mode and Build mode.  The story mode is where the real meat of Planet Explorers lies. You start off in a ship that crashed on the surface of a strange planet with only a few supplies at your disposal. From here on you need to scavenge various materials, complete objectives while fighting various hostile creatures and explore the planets and thus the name.Everything about Planet Explorers screams MMO. From the graphics to the mundane quests, Planet Explorers checks off every box in a MMO genre. First and foremost, you will be grinding a lot to create weapons and buildings but that is expected of a survival game in this age. What really impressed me was the variety present in the game. From the creatures that populate the planet to the amount of weapons and diverse buildings you can build inside the game, everything is varied and creates a truly alien atmosphere. When you start a game, you are given a few biomes to choose from including grasslands, forests etc. All these biomes are different not only in their visual style but in terms of their fauna. Every new biome had me looking for every new creature I could find and see what it did. Unlike a game like No Man’s Sky where the wildlife rarely attacks you or differs in their actual nature instead of only appearance, the creatures in Planet Explorers are a sight to behold and they cause you to flee in terror when you realize you do not have the proper equipments to actually withstand the mighty beasts. Even the smaller of creatures which appear non-alarming from a distance can easily overtake you when they approach in hordes. It’s a shame then that the combat in Planet Explorers is utterly lacking in depth. While the weapons are diverse, the feedback of these weapons are nothing more than firing a water gun. You don’t actually feel the impact of a sword striking a massive beast or a gun actually killing an enemy. The hitboxes in the game feel off and there is a certain disconnect between the player and the weapon he is wielding. The movement is also very clunky and the animations are very poorly designed. The building in Planet Explorers is pretty great though. When you have done the required grinding and are ready to build something magnificent, the building system comes into play. It is easy to use and if you have the required materials, you only need to pick and place the wanted blocks. It is one of the biggest strengths of Planet Explorers aside from its creatures and definitely has appeal to it. What lets it down though is the UI. While the diverse amount of weapons are good, it hampers the UI down. There are a lot of icons cluttering up the screen and you will more often than not lose an important item in your inventory because it gets so filled up and is difficult to separate from your other items. The Adventure mode is pretty similar to Planet Explorers. Here, instead of starting on a crashed spaceship, you start out in a town and get quests from various NPC’s. What separates it the most from the story mode is the fact that you can choose the biome on which you want to start and you will most likely get a headstart because of the available resources in the town. The Build mode is a mode where you are given a biome free of every creature and are left to explore and build. This mode is good for the people who really want to get in depth of the building system and such.There is also a certain lack of polish to the game which suggests it should have been in Early Access for a few more months as I am doubtful that the devs will continue to support it as they have been till now. The multiplayer is also pretty much dead and I was unable to join or create any game with other human players. VisualsThere are both good and bad parts to the game’s visuals. On one hand, the biomes look so diverse from each other and create beautiful vistas along with terrifying new creatures which intrigue your inner explorer while on the other hand, the human character models and the fighting animations are really bad. There is also a lot of texture pop in and that causes the player to break out of immersion.SoundFrom the get go, you are treated to one of the most beautiful soundtracks that could have accompanied this game. From the menu to the world itself, the soundtrack is so soothing and melodious that I found myself constantly just drowning down in it. There is no voice acting as to speak of but some of the creature sounds were simply amazing and to the point.OverallI would have more heartily recommended Planet Explorers had there not been a slew of other survival games on the market. It has some really nice ideas and has a huge potential but is still in need of fixing. Had it still been in early access, I would’ve hoped for the required polish but since it’s fully released, I have to recommend it but only when on a sale.Pros:Great atmosphereDiverse flora and faunaSoothing SoundtrackCons:Clunky movement and combatBad Combat AnimationsLots of bugsRating: 65/100This review was brought to you by Review Experts through the generous contribution of Daniël - REX ♥ Gaming

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								I absolutely recommend this game!As I described it to my roommate, it's like Minecraft and Skyrim had a baby in space. And it is fantastic!There are certainly still some bugs to work out; like written and spoken dialogue not matching up or having typos, at least one instance of a completely different character's dialogue from a completely separate mission being heard, and characters walking away while still talking to you.But that all pales in comparision to just how great the game is as a whole. The landscapes, plants, and creatures are all exceptionally crafted, incredibly alien, yet subtly familiar, too. The creatures run the gambit from squee inducing cuteness to don't-play-alone-in-the-dark scary to I-hope-that-colossal-thing-is-friendly. The different biomes feel very different from each other, yet blend seemlessly.Then there's what YOU can do! You can full sandbox it or follow storyline quests and sidequests. There's harvesting, learning ISO's (blueprints), crafting, and even making fully customizable weapons, vehicles, buildings, you name it. And when I say fully customizable, I don't mean you have a few skins to slap on or mods to click in place. I mean you can go as in depth as you want, from the ground up shaping or borrowing in game assets to create a wholly orginal item which is fully functional within the game.I'm incredibly excited to see them polish this gem so it shines the way it deserves when it leaves early access to become a full release.

content:

Early Access Review
								I found the game to be quite bland. It has a variety of landscapes and creatures, but they seem to be slapped together with an algorithm that doesn't make much sense and can make worlds seem awkward.Constructing anything seems needlessly complex, which makes producing anything not so much a challenge but a grinding task. Some may enjoy this but I find the cost/reward to be very imbalanced.For a voxel based game I found digging to be far too awkward and time consuming, which led me to avoid digging where ever possible.The vehicle construction is fun and I like the option to design your own weapons, too. I also enjoyed the variety of transport methods like jetpacks, helicopters and motorbikes.Planet Explorers is mediocre and there are many games that do each element better, but perhaps few that combine them into a singular game.

								I totally recommend this game, and a Big Praise goes out to the Dev's for the dedicated work they are doing in getting this game off the ground and flying. I have challenge the forum personnel as well with some different  attitudes they are well adjusted. and do their best to answer and help with Bug testing of the game. The game is well done though still has some bug issues that are being worked on. and some things still being added. personally i like that they are taking their time with the full release and the beta. Most Games come out half finished and not even playable anymore . PE is NOT one of those games. They care about what they are doing and this game and their Gamers. A few things i would like to see:Would like to see the Stand alone version updated. Some sound issue : needs a bit better equalization of sounds, around some water areas it's like white noise, but still playable. In another words the sounds all seem to wash together and becomes nearly white noise. Like to much wind with the water.Eating sounds needs toned down. Does need a better save system between the different modes of the game, instead of the one save in a bucket system(The game has 20 saves 3 of them are auto saves) have had it save a build save and it used all three of the auto saves with the same save. which deleted out the auto save of what i was doing in the story, you should be able to have a lot more hard saves in this section of the game as well. Though these are Birthing pains as it is for the game.Water and animals are good and the build system is good and they are improving even more on that system from what i can gather on the forums and the many posts i have read.The AI does need improving on, but that to is something they are working on, with some fix's to be out in the next update.Crafting is a breeze in the game, just get the materialsThe care system still needs some balancing ( Would like to see Water not just Food and a ton of medicines implemented in the game and not so much sickness,) these are suppose to be healthy bright individuals that do the colonization.  So some balancing there though i had read somewhere that this was still in flux on it's balancing. Need a better way to source water for the colony other then a Pitcher. All in all though the game is very well polished and the Dev's do listen to suggestions and problems and try to fix whats wrong. This is something i find to be a necessary as in a lot of games the Dev's seem to be nowhere to be found. These people are on the ball, and i praise them for that.As for Beta release, this game is close to it from what i can see, I can hardly wait.Just a Note: I set on the side lines for about a year and a half watching as this game Developed. I play mostly AAA games, even Beta ones like Warframe. I play Games 8 to 10 hours a day, One of my friends told i should check this one out again so i did and love the game.I've been gaming since Arcade was the only way to game, Have done Pro Beta Testing both in Closed Alpha and Closed and Open Beta and finished versions of games like Black Prophecy. ( thats a year and a half on 3 continents of Servers)  Have Admined many DayZ Servers and run a couple have done extensive mods of some games like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. and run fully Modded Servers for it and UT as well. and worked with a group of Modders. ( A whole different breed of people ) Have built gaming Forums and had one of my own. Also Admined them and set Moderators and the like. Have also been in a team building a gaming site or 2. So i know the dedication that is needed. They have that DedicationSo my hat is off to you and keep up the good work. I'll keep playing

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								The new sandbox experience. Please note: It seems that the 0.75 version (the first version uploaded to steam) has more features than I know of - I only played 0.72 (pre-steam) to the full extent of it.It's an alpha, so please do play the Demo before buying (and check the demo version since those could be outdated)!Be aware of the minimum system requirements! Also, saves can be incompatible between updates - if you don't like "wipes", you should probably wait!A beautiful, fun and full of potential game that features a very interesting Story Mode, great weapon/item/vehicle editor and easy-to-use build mode with free camera.There's also an Adventure mode (think Minecraft's Survival Mode - infinite randomly generated map), Build mode (Creative Mode) and also Multiplayer.Since the game is in early alpha, the storyline isn't complete yet, nor the editor or many other features, but you can already see the game shaping up very nicely and there's a decent amount of stuff to do already. Fun items like jetpacks, gliders and hooks are already in the game and only need a bit more polishing.The player-made vehicles (cars and helicopters, currently) and items (swords and guns) add a lot of nice content to play with.You'll also be able to make objects like tables and paintings, and put decals and effects on your creations.The (current) cons of the game comes from the fact that it's an early alpha. The movement/camera scheme can be a bit annoying at times, the optimization must be worked on, and a few other bugs regarding monster movement and AI, terrain loading and collision detection. But the developers are aware of all those issues, and are working on them (things that slightly annoyed me on 0.72 seem to have been fixed/improved on recent versions).The plotline is very interesting and engaging - I can't wait until they write more and put more quests & story in the game! The remaining features you can easily read & watch videos on, or discover for yourself on the demo.The game is worth it and I hope it succeeds and the development goes on smoothly.Along with Starbound, it's one of the most worthy sandbox games to watch currently.Have fun! :D

Simply does not work on Mac. Launches a black screen and crashes. I could play it through bootcamp, but if you're going to advertise it as Mac compatible, it should at least launch. From the developer: "The 600M and 700M series have a crash bug right now that we're looking at".... That was in March of 2014.  So not only did they know that there's an issue, but they've continued to advertise it as being mac compatible for YEARS now, and it still doesn't work. "But Steve, it's still in Early Access!"... Plague on society. If you're going to charge money to have people "involved" in your game, it has to launch. If it can't at least run when you hit the play button, it's not even ready for EA. Period. More and more companies are using early access as an excuse to get money without being accountable, and it's a shame.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I don't usually review games good or bad, but I had to make an exception  in  this case. First off, I have always been an adventure game lover and especially sandbox games, but in recent years I have started to enjoy exploring and survival games. After many so so games I finally ran across this one. I couldn't be more excited. I have been playing story mode for 5 days...wasting the entire 5 days off work with this game. The graphics are beautiful and unique, the story flows well and I never seem to get tired of mining and crafting. There is always something better right around the corner or from the next quest.  The battling is great too. Some animals will kill you in one or two hits and you can never carry enough ammo to kill some of them...takes turrets (of which there are plenty). The instructions aren't the best, but that is what keeps it interesting. Trying to figure things out rather than just having them outlined for you. Then there's the crafting. This is absolutely the best crafting system I have ever used. Once you find/buy/are awarded the scripts, just click it and it cascades into everything you need, and if you don't have an item, just click it and it again tells you what you need to make that. It is totally awesome. Now, flying machined, jeeps, boats, subs...you name it and you can create it, or just use a premade template in game. The creation system leaves a bit to be desired and has a steep learning curve, but seems rather simple once you get the hang of it. The building system on the other hand is a virtually useless. If nothing else, it makes it easy to make a wall or a floor etc, but the shapes don't seem to have much use, or at least not with any sort of effective tutorial, and that is another weak point...the tutorials. Pro's: Great graphics. Awesome creation system. Great story line that keeps you engrossed and adds some mystery. Gathering is great. Nice mix of primitive to modern/space age tools and systems. Great upgrades for everything. Critters for days. Can't really say enough good things about it. Con's:  Building system. Tutorials. Locked keys, can't bind tab and q for movement which SUX for me. Over all I am 100% satisfied for the first time in a very long time.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								I hate early access games. I think that whilst the principle is nice, it's far too tempting for devs to take the money and not deliver on their promises. But this game has interested me from the time I first saw it. I've been looking for a good survival and crafting experience that doesn't rely on multiplayer and all the griefers that come with it. This game offers that in what is already an impressive array of single player and co-op experiences. Yes it is still noticeably alpha in some areas but the important things all work well and the graphics are good for a game of this type. I'm still discovering new creatures and elements and it sounds like there will be more added by the time it's finished. Building and crafting is very simple and intuitive. I was impressed that the story mode had at least some voice acting, hopefully they finish it off for all the quests and maybe add more than just the 2 or 3 soundtracks they've got.But yes looking at the other games offering similar experiences I am satisfied that at the moment this one offers the best experience for those who want an exploration game without forced multiplayer. The direction it's heading at the moment it seems it will end up as a combination of Elder Scrolls, DayZ and Minecraft, blending them all together for something unique.Obligatory throw away line: "It's like skyrim with aliens - 10/10"

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Planet Explorers is the makings of a great game.In its current state, it is clear that it is an alpha. This isn't to say it is intolerable. As a matter of fact, it is remarkbly put together for an alpha. As advertised, there is a campaign mode. It is a surprisingly interesting story about tensions between Martians and Earthlings (both human), as well as a believeable "first contact" scenario. The writing isn't ground-breaking, but it is definitely better than many cookie-cutter stories released nowadays. Regretably with much of the important dialog missing voice overs, it can be difficult to follow. Granted, some people adore Morrowind style dialog, but much of the important voice overs are missing throughout the game. For example, it is very common to be ambushed in the story and forced to run. The problem is that there is no audio that plays signifying a retreat. This can be mildly frustrating, especially when you are killed thinking your teammates are backing you up.Many of the games descriptions can leave you lost or downright confused. Two examples: when you are picking something up, the button you click is "Get". Not "Take" or "Pickup", but the awkward verb "Get". In addition, quest descriptions can confuse you. Such as receiving a quest with in the first hour to start a colony, only to find out that you need to complete a quest 5 hours in to fulfil that quest. But I digress...The art direction is rather impressive. Jungles feel thick and plains are reminiscent of rolling wheat farms while still having still having an alient quality to them. It is clear that some of the creatures that inhabit Maria are inspired by apes, cats, and dogs, but the artists did a wonderful job distancing from many obvious qualities. Be it multiple armed, hairless, ape-like creatures, or pseudo-tiki faced giraffe creatures, the game will always take what you expect and tweak it so that only base features are recongizable. It is a shame that the game doesn't have a strong backing, because it is clear that the artists are talented in making the familiar seem alien.Graphically, it is passable. It has its moments of beauty, such as watching the sunrise shine through a mass of tree branches. The biggest gripe I have is the combat in the game. Melee is a wonderful way to ensure you die repeatedly, which is fair when you're fighting creatures that are usually 2x larger than you. The main problem is the lack of a basic notification for when you deal/take damage to/from a creature. It leaves most of the combat to be spamming attack, holding shield, then spamming, all while staring at your health bar. With the vehicles, I can see damage notifiers in the form of numbers, which almost feels taunting. Another problem with the combat is the random difficulty spikes. For instance, while in the mountain/desert regions, I moved from quest point to quest point willy-nilly, but once I reached a random point, I got killed in one laser blow. Repeatadly. The only warning was "Take these turrets! It is our only hope!" And before you ask, the turrets didn't seem to help me. This is forgiveable however. As it is an alpha, the primary focus isn't on balance but in addition of promised features. And thankfully, there is plenty to do as you gain stronger resources.Finally, the most important component: the weapon/vehicle editor. It is clear that it is a robust system, if a little difficult to learn. I am not the most creative person, so I have difficulty putting my plans to editor. Thankfully, it is simple to download ISO files (the files that are used as "saves" for the different created objects) and install. While you are forced to download from the game's forums, this game has a pretty strong case for Steam Workshop integration. All things together, the game is currently in a very accessable alpha. A creativity akin to Spore & Minecraft's community filters through every facet in gameplay, be it through developer or player. If you are a fan of exploration games and creative building, you won't be disappointed by this game. Even if you don't buy today, I really recommend keeping an eye on this game cause I only see it getting better and better.

								I really would like to try this game again in the future but for now I cannot recommend it. In my opinion it still requires more bug fixes.I've been waiting on this game for about 18 months to move forward in progress, but it still appears to be aggravating and clunky. I play the game in 4k and even though it allows for the resolution it is certainly not set up for it. My firearms shoot about 3 inches lower than the reticle and monsters still attack through structures and the ground while I am mining and crafting. The game has been out for some time now and I figured coming back to it that a lot of these issues would be dealt with. I guess not..Pros:Graphics are pretty good @ 4kMusic is pretty good as wellVoxel creative tool is still awesome(I could spend hours in it)Interface is intuitiveCons:Gameplay is clunkyBugs remain that were present in the game 18 months ago.4k Resolution problems(Read above)I guess I will check back in another 18 months.

								Think Minecraft but with all the stuff you wished minecraft had...Its a great game, combat is nicly done but wish there was a dangerous night setting or other such so more enemies spawn / attack the player forcing them to actually have a base...Some quests in the story mode need work on clarifing objectives (escort said person... doesnt have a to where).The ability to make your own items (especially weapons) is epic, it takes awhile to do but that just adds to the fun when you're finally using a sword that looks how you want it to look.Love how you can place many blocks at once, oddly if the cell count exceeds the block count (even if it wont exceed block usage) it sometimes prevents placment.. odvious work-around is if you want to place a 8x8x1 patch then have more than 16 blocks.^Also love how you can put the blocks in the shape you want, so a ramp, bumb, spike, curb, ect... and place that all the same as normal blocks so if you want a spiked wall you can do it in a matter of seconds.Its a great game and I highly recommend it to minecraft players, and people who love open world sandbox games.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Wow, an Early Access game that's actually more complete and more fun than many "release" games. This is what StarForge should have been: consider it a Sci-Fi Minecraft with better graphics and all the cool gun/flight/ship/monster mods already installed. Unlike many prereleases, everything you see in the videos above is totally possible with the current build... and then some. Planet Explorers is fast becomming a dream come true. If your computer can handle it, BUY IT NOW, you will not be disappointed.Pros: Realistic terrain, an RPG storyline, followers (2!), hunting, mining, farming... excellent crafting... did I  mention crafting? Axes, guns, lasers... use prefab ones, or even design your own using a built-in 3D editor. Build motorcycles... tanks... jets... a helicopter... totally customized... you can even paint them and add decals, then share them with friends and other players. Just... wow.Cons: UI is still a little clunky, especially in the 3D designer, the "follower" AI is far from perfect, especially if leading NPCs underground or between trees, and there are a few quest annoyances, none of which are game breaking. The good news is the developers push out regular updates and are VERY responsive to customer input.Even in alpha, this one is a must-have.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is one of the rare gems that I have seen in the latest trend of Voxel game engines.  If it continues in it's current direction, it will be one of the best games that I have played in the last 20 years. Machine Specs:    i5 OC @ 4.4 Ghz - Nvidia 660 - 16gb 2400 MhzFPS (High Settings): 60+ Summary The game is in an alpha - so the story line is not complete.  There is about 20 hours of playable story content, and what I have seen is extremely interesting. They have the potential to weave a great story out of this game and are headed in the right direction.It is a hybrid of a FPS/BF1942 (Yes, the old one) land, sea, air combat - mixed into the crafty style of minecraft, splashed with colony/base management & building. The game uses a Voxel engine, written in Unity, and while I am not always a fan of Unity 3D based engines (Mainly due to it having such a low barrier to entry - so you get alot of shotty development teams using it), but this game is written so that you would think it's using CryEngine or some custom engine. It has no signs of Unity slowness. There is a huge technology / crafting tree..  Its not perfectly balanced, but it is so engrossing, that I think they will have no trouble balancing it. The crafting works well.. the UI is intuitive and makes it a good experience.They have a unique system for 'scanning' for minerals - which makes finding materials much easier and helps with base/colony planning. A great idea.. and it also looks amazing. There is a great system for crafting your own items/weapons/aircraft/boats/cars - the system is easy to use, reminds me a bit of Google Sketchup, except with voxels - and is fairly realistic in material usage, weight, and physics (IE.. heavy planes don't fly)They allow you to import models from other users in ISO format - which is a great feature if you are lazy like me and really don't wan to spend hours painting and building a really cool ship. All of the importing is integrated using Steam Workshop - so its' very seamless.. It reminds me of the model importing from Spore.The multiplayer is still immature - most servers are lowly populated - but it is an Alpha game, so I suspect that will change in the future.  It has a bit of the DayZ appeal in multiplayer, so I think this part will come around as game development progresses.  It offers Adventure, Surival, and Coop modes - but there  is no Coop for Story mode.  Game Development The game does not feel like an Alpha at all..  The game is fairly stable. I have seen a few crashes due to array indexing issues, but for the most part, its not bad. The developers have pushed content on a regular basis and seem to be a very worthy team capable of completing this project. I have no fears that my cash used on this project will yield a solid product. This is one of the few Early Access projects that I have jumped on where I feel like I immediately got a return on my investment. There is a playable demo available at their main site too..  It would be nice if they would add it to steam and maintain it, but that may not be easily done. Graphics EngineThe game uses Unity - but the graphics are quite nice.  I've done a bit of indie work with Unity 3D and until I read about it on the forums, I couldn't tell it was a Unity based game. The only real visual hint is that the frill is batched, which shows up in open plains areas.The terrain blending is done to perfection.. mineral types make sense, the textures look realistic to the terrain (IE.. no gold rock sticking up in the middle of the terrain).  The forests are lush and all of the models are well done. The animations are 'ok' - though they could use a bit of work, but it is an Alpha, so no worries on that getting cleaned up. On my system, it runs very smoothly - renders distant terrain without issue and feels very well optomized. It is processor intensive and uses a large amount of RAM (4gb after playing a while) - so if you have a system with less than 8gb - you will likely see some slowness loading the areas (They make heavy use of caching..)The minimum system specs are really low.. I don't see how you could have a fun play experience with just those specs. Game PlayThe gameplay is fun..  even the crafting isn't bad (I'm not a fan of minecraft/free form building). It has several game modes, Adventure, Story, and Free Build (unlimited resources) -  so it caters to a variety of play styles. I see alot of potential in the story - if they can pull it off..   Multi-content base battles.. large battleships (all destructible), very similar to the combat of BF 1942 or PlanetFall.  The best part is that it is voxel base, so the entire world is destructible/buildable. The story starts off very slow.. I had this game in my library a few times.. thought it was just another voxel garbage game - so I didn't give it much of a chance.  If you play the story, give it atleast two hours as it can be very overwhelming at first and will easily turn you away. However, consider the story to be more of a tutorial on the interface.  It gets better after you get into the vehicle/guns part and actually turns into an intrigueing story of alien races/who did it/why are we here.. This game is lightyears ahead of Landmark - the only other engine I've seen come close to doing what it does. Overall.. this is one of the best games I've seen in 2014 and has so much potential and seems to be backed by the developers who can pull it off. If you understand that the game is an alpha and that your story will most likely be spoiled by playing early (before it is complete) then this a definate buy for your library.  However, I would recommend waiting on the story to be complete as my only disappointment in this game was reaching the point in the story where it was incomplete (I really wanted to play on.. it was addicting, fun and a great experience)

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I waited over two years to write this review. I wanted to write a good review back when this was early access. It was really good back then, for a time being. At some point one of the updates made the optimization terrible. I'm able to run the newest games coming out and wasn't able to play this game above 15 FPS. I remembered how fun it was though, and waited. Hoping they would eventually fix the issues. I kind of forgot about it for a while, till just this last week. I saw it had been released and thought I'd give it another shot.I'm pleased to say it's better than it was, I mean it's finished so that's to be expected and all. I'd recommend this game to anyone really. There is enough here for people to play the way they want. It does the whole voxel thing, which some people don't like. It does it better than most games do however. If you were snake bitten by no man's sky or those "spaceraria" type games. This one will scratch the itch. You're on only one planet, but you can tell from the screenshots alone that there is a lot to experience. Almost everything is customizable, which a lot of people are going to like. I just want to give one warning about that. Play and beat the main story line first, then go crazy with the custom weapons and such. The reason I say this is because pretty early on you can make custom weapons and basically overpower yourself right from the get go. If you don't have a problem with that, and that's what you're looking for then... well that's now an option you know. There is too much for me to point out, just know that this is an amazing game. I'm glad the developers kept working on it and didn't abandon it. It shows and more people should play this game.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								A lot of potential here. Though it's not quite yet to all be realized.Monster Hunter is one of my favorite franchises.I also love Dark Souls.I also love Terraria, Dwarf Fortress, Minecraft, etc.I love jRPGs, open world games, survival, exploration, etc.I also love MMOs.At a glance, this game seems to be all of those things (minus the massively multiplayer part).Execution-wise, it still has a bit to go.I'm aware it's early access, so I'm just hoping all these things get addressed soon.Large monsters walking about, and you have the ability to craft weapons and fight them which looks like a typicalMonster Hunter battle or a Dark Souls boss -- only mechanics have yet to catch up.It feels clunky at best. The hit boxes are unclear, and the enemies don't seem to follow a set logic.Also the lack of real movement options for the player -- rolling being the key one, and the lack of attack animationsthat are conducive to this kind of gameplay really pulls the experience down.I found myself avoiding these fights more than not.It's not a skill issue, either. I would classify myself as "good" to "Very good" at monster hunter, and "well-versed" in Dark Souls.I appreciate a challenging game and a challenging control interface. I like to take difficult encounters and learn themuntil I can beat them untouched and unharmed.That being said, I found that next to impossible to do even on the easiest of enemies.The method of combat thus far does not seem to be to outskill your prey, but rather to out-tech it with armor and weaponsuntil its damage and defense becomes negligible to your own.Exploration is fun, but could be streamlined a bit and sped up.Being that it is not massivelty multiplayer, making mining and chopping wood take arbirtarily long amounts of time don't haveany meaningful reason. It's a single player game that focuses on mining and exploration, so let the exploration feel fun.Tune the amount you dig, the way you dig, and how fast you dig to better reflect this.Though that sounds like a lot of criticsm, I do in fact enjoy this game. I played it a lot before picking it up on Steam. I still continue to jump in and play every now and then.I am looking forward greatly to upcoming patches.This has potential to be one of my favorite games.I'm hoping the developers pull through.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you've got a creative bone in your body, you'll love this game. If you loved building amazing things in Minecraft out of materials that you patiently (and often painfully) harvested yourself, you'll probably love this game. It contains a lot of the things people have come to love from creative adventure/survival games and then throws nice visuals and a pretty rad story mode on it like its no big deal.The game is no way polished and pretty just yet (its early access), but by playing it, you'll realize just how much amazing potential this game has. I've been following this game and playing it pretty casually for the past year and it found it really interesting how connected the developers were with their community - often seeing developers pick up on suggestions from the forums. When the game updates, the updates are usually worth checking out.My complaints for the game are minimal and will very likely be worked out by release - things like not-so-great voice acting for NPCs in the Story Mode, the incomplete character creation section, the limited/poor sounds and music, having to hold AI companions hands a lot, and generally strange monster AI behavior.If you're feeling iffy about the purchase, just wait for final release, It'll likely be a different animal worth way more than its current price tag.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has the potential to be a big deal, but like any other indev game, it needs work.First, I'll talk about the positive things the game offers at the moment. Environment- The world has such an original look to it. There's a huge variety of trees, greenery, and plants, all of which are obtainable, can be interacted with, and all have their own uses. This brings such a rich experience to adventuring, something a lot of other voxel games don't seem to understand. Variety. Wildlife - I absolutely love the critters you come in contact with in this game. They are all so unique, and so diverse. It really does feel like a world that could exist. I have to admit, this is what pulled me in to this game. Some creatures are hostile towards you, some are passive, and some are only hostile if provoked. There is also a touch of ecology with the animals. Some animals prey on others, so again, this is something that really helps make the world feel alive. You got the Hoolock Gibbon, a small goblin/monkey type creature that travels in packs and will attack with rocks if threatened, the Testudo Mariturtle that is breathtakingly massive, and much much more in between. Just watching them walk around is an experience (especially in the forest). What I hope to get out of this game in the future is more AI with creatures. I would love to see specific creatures eat and forage their own favorite vegetation, and interact with the player and other creatures in many other different ways. Interaction - Imagine playing a game like Skyrim, now imagine that you can interact with everything in the world. Chop down trees, dig a hole in the ground, carve your own cave out of the side of a mountain, whatever you wish. This is what Planet Explorers offers. You can mine loads of different materials, whether it be marble or limestone, and build with it as you please There are loads of shapes to choose from. You can make ramps, stairs...ummm...pointy thingies. Seriously, there is no limits here. This is voxel at its finest.Customization - Planet Explorers takes interaction to the next level. With the materials that you obtain in the game, you can make your own weapons (Whether it be guns or melee weapons), and vehicles (whether it be for the ground or the air). Literally create the look, the size, and the color. This is an amazing feature. Now, I have to say, it can be a bit overwhelming, and it requires a good deal of learning, but in this case, learning is rewarding. There is truly no limit to what you can make.Now, for the things that need work. Controls- This game begs, and I mean begs to have better first person controls. I find that the game is so much more immersive in first person, and it DOES have a first person perspective, but a lot of things you need to do are more convenient in the 3rd person. Doing some things in first person makes it feel as though you're taking an extra, unnecessary step. I find myself accidentally going out of first person because I forget you can't scroll through your items in your hotbar. You have to use the number keys. Also, while in first person, interacting with some things is very tedious. You can't look down as far as you need to sometimes, and this makes it difficult to mine.  I understand that being in first or third is all about preference, but first needs a lot more love. Difficulty - Now, this is a tricky one to explain. Simply put: Most enemies in this game are too damn hard to fight. Yes, with good equipment, it can get easier, but there is a very thin line between weak enemy and strong enemy right now. Some enemies take too long to put down. It's not about enemies taking time to figure out as much as its about their HP being too high. Like I said, better equipment makes battles go by quicker, but a lot of these enemies can be encountered waaay before you get the equipment suited to fight them. You can go through a whole set of arrows and still not have taken down an enemy. It's time consuming in a weird way. Item display - This isn't really a big one on my list, but it is an issue for me. It can be very hard to see what items are, and what your quantity is. I find myself squinting to see how much meat I have, and most of the time, just guess. I would like to see in the future a way to hover over items which would allow for a zoomed in display of them.  Okay, I'm done. A lot of these cons are simply things that need work, and by what I've read, it's going to get it. This isn't actually negative criticism. I'm simply reviewing the game for what it is now. As a whole, the game is well worth attention, and I have no doubt that when completed, it will be amazing. I recommend this one for sure for people who enjoy watching games grow.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												Note: This review was done at release, not before.Compared to other survival games, this one hits a solid middle of the road at best. @25 bucks, it's not worth the price. For the quality of game, it's not worth the time.Here's why:ProsTheir item/vehicle creator will let you build just about anything. Really, it's pretty good.Co-Op Story in a survival game.You can roll male or femaleIt's very pve-centric (one of the few multiplayer survival games focused on pve)You can build a colony, very cool concept.ConsSaid item creator has a bit of a learning curve (about 2-3 hours to get it down)It's survival, but not as good as 7 Days or Ark.It's got adventure, but the adventure is numb after about 5 hours.Controls feel wobbly / delayed.Character creation is stylized, but circa 2003It's got combat, but the controls make combat feel "meh".This is the big one: There's this haze filter over EVERYTHING used to trick you into it having good graphics.Bugs galore - I just tried to create a coop game with the wife, our first act was to start item duping out of the starter chest.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												This is a beautiful game with a great soundtrack though admittedly I turn the music off to make the game more atmospheric. If I was better at iso crafting I'd make a jurassic park styled jeep because I feel like I am in that movie while driving through the jungles. I'm not so I'll just keep my eye out for someone else to make a good iso. The creatures are amazing and story mode actually provides a good story while adventure mode generates unique maps for replayability. One downside is that even with normal mode, which is the hardest mode available at the moment, the game is not very hard to survive. It can be a little slow at the beginning when you only have wood tools but once you start finding better scripts the game gets easy. Pretty soon you get a pulse rifle and type 2+ armor and you run around in adventure mode effortlessly soloing level 9 and 10 dungeons for the custom items they randomely reward you at the end.If you enjoy the freedom to build whatever you can imagine provided you are willing to devote time and effort then this game is for you. If you enjoy casual survival games with no real penalty for death then this game is for you. If you like sight-seeing across very large randomely generated maps full of flora and fauna then this game is for you.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
Early Access Review
http://www.cublikefoot.com/planet-explorers-first-impressions/Planet Explorers is a solid third-person exploration game with a lot of content, even in early access.There's so much to do in the game, so much I've yet to do. I spent most of my time fooling around, fighting random animals, exploring caves, and just generally doing nothing productive. Planet Explorers combines its excellent gameplay with some great ambience, an awesome soundtrack, and some pretty nice graphics. It is in early access, so the game is not without its flaws. I ran into a few bugs while playing, plenty of "getting stuck in the map" situations. Hopefully the game becomes more polished as it reaches a release date.Planet Explorers earns my recommendation. although I still have plenty to learn about the game. Can't wait for an actual release!

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Well, lets sum it up:Good graphics : only the animations do not have much variety, but they said it will be fixed in the future updates, and they are really doing it so a 10/10, even if it is not from some big money seeking coorporation like ubisoft or EA GAMES (no offense to them of course).The music : Good, i hope they add more tracks to the game, but the main menu song reminds me of Two Steps From Hell, Audiomachine, Adrian Von Ziegler, Thomas bergerson or Jo Blankenburg.It sounds just soo good to me! 8/10 for variety, if more music and war songs like to glory or fallen army from GRV music, then it would be a 9/10 or even 10/10campaign : IT IS BIG, i mean not big but BIG BIG, i mean, you get like 20 square kilometers to do whatever you want. build a bunker, a big freaking colony, it all depends on your imagination and possibilities. also of recources and enemies and surroundings of course! a 10/10 for that one! (in my opinion)Possibilities : ENORMOUS! design your own chair, weapon, vehicle, dreadnought, spaceship, whetever the heck you want, AND USE IT IN SINGLEPLAYER AND MULTIPLAYER! (campaign works too!) so a 10/10 for that one!Multiplayer :Good, 3 gamemodes : adventure, cooperation and VS mode. then we have more generation options for the map like river width and depth, map size to limitless from 4x4 km. so it is big, we have a infinite recource mode to suit your testing(-grounds ;D )you even have a leveling in multiplayer and a role info, that shows what kind of roles you do and if your good at that. they will expand it with the updates.a 8/10Character creation : YES YOU CAN MAKE YOUR OWN CHARACTER!not like in skyrim of course, but it gets the immersion a bit better done!hair, skin color , body parts, all you need. not much hair types but a 9/10 for the possibility to even create your own character!Politics :That will be implanted soon. no score for that yet.Colony:You can have your own colony in campaign and adventure mode!pretty sweet, because you can build your own buildings and make the interiors to your taste!~make a frigging castle, i don't care, but it has to keep your citizens safe from aliens of all kinds, from small little irritating bugs to titan walking exterminators that destroy everything with they're full armanents.you can build turrets, upgrade the buildings and make your own custom buildings, that the game will script and use like a base or something else.A 8/10, if more upgrades would be implanted to the core building and secondary buildings, that would be good, and worth a higher number!NPC'S :Well you have citizens in your colony and you can appoint them to do various jobs, from farming to fighting and mining or fishing and cutting trees. some can't fight but they can mine, because they have no strength to do the fighting part. sometimes tough some npc's can't do sh*t and they just eat all your food, soo, have some good NPC'S in your colony! a reminder : you get your first colony later in the campaign mode, and faster in adventure mode.try to understand the factors that play when you are leading a colony. like happiness or food and fuel to fuel the buildings.A 9/10 for this one!The first person mode will be back in alpha 0.90A .the developers of the game say they will also do more impact improvements and animation fixing, so it will be a big update. and i also understand it can come out later than the 0.90A version. so don't get mad if it is the 0.90A version and you still can't get to 1-st person mode!And at last a 10/10 for the hardworking people that are making this game for us!~a good game where you don't need to pay 50 bucks for and get only 30 hour's main campaign and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ multiplayer!KEEP UP THE GOOD WORK DEVELOPERS OF PLANET EXPLORERS!and I hope I helped you with the preview of this good game!Have a nice day everyone,greetings, Daniel.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								I won't go into a lot of details of the gameplay. If you want a review on that look further in the other reviews. My review is based on two things: my experiance playing the game as of nearly 2 years ago and the current build of this game as of July 12, 2016.I remember a time when Alpha builds were considered proof of concept builds that were for in-company testing only. The product at that point had enough in it that the vision and basis to continue developement was clear and sound but would lack enough content to release publically for beta testing. Beta builds of a product meant that they has passed the preliminary in-house testing and featured enough development and content that it was suitable to release for public beta testing. This game... this game came out on steam early 2014 and now, 2 years later, it hasn't even entered Beta stage testing. What does this translate to? Well it doesn't mean it is a bad game. It doesn't mean that this game won't ever be completed. It isn't a prediction on the quality of the game when it is finally completed. What it DOES mean is that if you are thinking of getting this game... DON'T. Seriously, just don't. At least not yet. Come back in 5 years when this game MAY have finally exited beta stage and moved on to full release. Until then you are going to just end up paying $25 for a glorified psuedo demo with less content and more bugs than a real demo.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note: I originally had this as a thumbs down, but the creation kit has changed my mind.  This game has great potential, but has a number of issues associated with its alpha state.  The game basically has four play modes: -- Story; which does exactly what it says on the tin.  - Adventure; in which you jump into the world with some friendly NPC's and the foundations of a settlement to build upon once you have collected the prerequisite materials. - Build; in which you are given free reign and unlimited materials to build whatever you want.  - Multi-player; in which you can set up a server with friends/ family.  The Bad: -The combat is sluggish, locks you into animations and largely involves swinging a stick in the general vicinity of monsters.  The controls for vehicles (especially helicopters) need a rework (they are simply poorly realised currently). The build and multi-player modes barely work, the map in build mode has such short draw distances that the use of any vehicle results in you driving off the edge of the map and dieing.  The story mode is the most complete, but it does involve some needless time sinks, and needs a lot more polish.  It also stops part way through while the remainder is in development- but provides circa 20 hours of gameplay currently.    The Good: -The story mode is fun (but is orientated towards gathering and crafting). The creation system, in which you can design weapons and vehicles (wheel based or rotor based), is the high point of the game.  Certain pre-made items are required such as a cockpit or energy cells, but beyond this you can create almost anything you set your mind upon.  Of course to use these items in game (other than in the buggy build mode) you will need to collect the materials first.  There are limitations to the system, for example, building a vast rectangle with rotors all over it will give you better overall stats than taking the time to build a realistic, aerodynamic chopper.  Look at the time I have spent in game, most of them have been spent in the creation system.  If this appeals to you, this game is worth buying.  In conclusion; this is clearly an alpha game, and as such it lacks a lot of polish and features, and is fairly buggy.  Once the development has progressed it should be great fun.

								I backed this game on Kickstarter so I've been playing it for a while. It's a lot of fun. I suggest you go look at the updates on their Kickstarter page and view the Changelist in prior releases to see what I mean.I haven't tried multiplayer yet, but think I will give it a go sometime soon.I have no doubt this game is bound for(What I would consider) greatness.

Early Access Review
								     I've been burned so many times on early access games showing me a demo video, then me buying it, and half the functionality is there.  Well I'm happy to say, this is not the case.  It's everything its advertised to be and more.    If you're a gamer, you'll understand the following: "Its like Minecraft had sex with Starforge, then WoW was genetically infused with its off-spring."  I know there are many more games you can swap out for that analogy, but bar none this has been the early release game of its type.  Good job and high-fives to the devs.     P.S.  A little about the game-  There is a whole lot to do.  I'd suggest new players start out with story mode so you can understand the crafting aspect of the game.  Then, if your so inclined, go over to adventure more (survival mode) and get to building that awesome base with a helicopter pad and garage so you can really dominate this planet.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have been playing this game from back in version 0.4 and was very impressed with it back then and still am today. I am a very big fan of voxel games and sandbox building games and when you add in the 'distant planet in the future' factor, that was a huge hook for me. Gathering and creating is very well implemented and feels nice. The ability to custom build your weapons and vehicles is so well done that it can take hours (If you want to spend that log that is) to make something. This game still is in early access so the only complaints I have are moot because they will be addressed. First, the control of your character is blocking and weird at time, not smooth at all. Secondly, the difficulty is too high when you first start out and then you turn into god as soon as you get any decent weapon. And lastly, and I know I am being nit picky, when it rains it will show up inside your home even if it is closed up. All things said, if you are a fan of sandbox games or voxel games, get this game!

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								I enjoy exploration in games. I usually put on my own music via Google music and enjoy wandering around, getting lost and stopping to look at the world around me. This game is one of the best Ive come across for this type of gameplay.  You're thrown on to an alien world and you have to survive but things are not so dire that you have to constantly fight the entire time. It's paced wonderfully. The alien life is great to discover, plant and animals. Not every mob is out to attack on site. you can walk right up to all kinds of friendly animals, big and small, and get a closer look at them. I really like that. There is digging, mining, crafting and all the things most everyone is familiar with by now. However, the graphics are excellent and the landscape is a smooth, sloped surface. Nothing like the blocky voxels that most games produce. I have only been playing this game for a few weeks. Got it about 3 weeks before it hit Steam so I haven't even gotten into the heart of the game by base building, multiplayer, farming and vehicle creation. But going by the first 6 hours i've played it is amazing. A game I can get completely immersed in. With the updates the devs have planned this could be one of my all-time favorites. I searched many months for a particular game to scratch a beautiful exploration itch and I found it in Planet Exploreres. Buy this game.The video I am sharing is from the 0.72 alpha version. Before the 0.75 that was the initial Steam version. and the music playing is not in game music.


YouTube™ Video: Planet Explorers: Getting Started (episode 1) 

			Views: 181		

			This is my favorite new game. It's a gorgeous sandbox adventure rpg game based on exploration, gathering resources, building and questing on an alien planet.
