For the casual gamers maybe wait for a later beta or finished product or you'll find yourself stuck for hours trying to build a flintstones car just to progress the storyline.  I dread the day I have to build things that fly.

								For such an early build, I find this game amazingly fun, and beautifully constructed.Vibrant biomes, many different and interesting wildlife (With more coming), and a storyline I find interesting and want to see more of.The crafting system is amazing, with an ingame 3D builder you can design your own vehicles and weapons, and upload them for others to use in thier games.  http://isoplanetexplorer.com/ is already full of amazing and well crafted items//vehicles for you to try out in your own game.With the different game modes, Story, Adventure and Build mode.  It can be shaped to any style of gameplay you want.Have not tried multiplayer yet, but sounds like the ability to run around this world with friends would be great fun.Worth the price, just to back the developer and ensure an amazing final product, but is worth it for even the amount of fun this stage of development offers.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing even in alpha stage. I never had so much thrills thinking of how muchpotential this game has. It's a voxel based game which means the graphics will never be quite goodbut having amazing futures no other sandbox, that i know about, has yet makes up for that. For example an ingame 3D modeling tool. Takes a moment to learn but hit me it's amazing.You can pretty much build anything you like. And with a click of button you have it inside your game. Be it a railroad, spaceship, castle, weapon, car, shield. You will be able to create pretty much anything. The game automaticallycalculates the amount of materials needed to build your creation in game. Giving you a pretty much instant access to a gamewhere you can make your own game in. Limited by the engine of course.The futures it has so early in development makes me glad i bought early access. The devs behindthis needs all the cash they can get so they can make one of the most creative sandbox game today.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Some people when seeing this game will immeditely think "Yay... another Minecraft clone... again!" and would be partly right since this game offers a lot more.First : the story mode, which could potentially be considered a big tutorial for the adventure part, is actually worth doing if you are (like myself) an amateur of the "stranded adventures" type, in many occasions I almost expected Captain Janeway beam down and give me a new assignment.Second : the customization possibilities go way beyond what Minecraft can do (coming from the madman who made the casle of Akashi on minecraft-europe server mostly by himself), both in terms of objects AND in vehicules with some really impresive designs you can import in the game just with a drag and drop in the right folder, even while the game is till running.Third : the environments are gorgeous ! I was a bit scared to end up in pretty barren lands like you could see in Anarchy Online but through the visual style (which reminds a lot of Consortium and/or Star Wars - The Old Republic), props and mobs runing around you already have, despite the game being in alpha, the impression of being in a living world. It really is a joy to see a pack of wolf like creature attacking a herbivore in the middle of a forest. Some may argue that the graphics are not "Next-Gen" but as Yathzee Croshaw would say "Golden pixels are detrimental to the quality of all other aspects of the game" yet even though the game is definitely not the absolute best looking you can tell the guys put some serious work in making the environments colourful and interesting to travel in (I had to pick up my jaw on the floor a few times in fact).On the less good parts :- The game currently has some issues with quest in story mode blocking (a character giving a quest that pops up and dissappear right away or conditions not validating being the most common issues), some people apparently didn't had much problems but I'm currently stuck after 12 hours of questing. Probably somethings patching will correct so I don't mind that much.- You can shape the land as you see fit in theory only because it is actually quite difficult to accurately mine things, for example trying to mine a perfectly straight tunnel at an angle can become a nightmare really fast because the character is always sliding on slopes, which brings to the next point.- Controls are a bit cluncky with a big hindrance of the camera not always placing itself in the best angle for the action and the vehicules being a bit difficult to accurately tune in regards to the power/weight ratio and turning angle, meaning a vehicule can have a tendency to do a 180° as slowly as an narcoleptic sloth or beat Sonic the hedgehod to it.The last point is nor good nor bad, it's actually something any off roader knows : there are no roads (that I've seen) on this planet so do not build a low hanging vehicule as the slightest slope will probably damage the vehicule. So unless you manually build roads leading to New Rome you will always travel in bugies !

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Absolutely an amazing game. So much to do. It is a sandbox game meaning you can do practically anything you want with out following a story line. However, there is a story and it is a good one. You crash on a new planet with a few other scattered survivors. As in real life you have to survive and try to get off planet or at least hook up with others.  In order to do this you mine materials, grow food, build habitations,forts,base camps,even villages.You create tools,weapons,machines,ATVs, aircraft etc. You hunt animals for meat which is also a currency, and harvest plants for mediciane. You scan the earth for minable resources.Some of the local fauna are passive some aggressive and you need to be alert and armed where ever you go. This adds a feeling of danger and realness to the game. As it would be in real life you learn about the planet through exploration, about its creatures through study and careful approach. All have there own biorythms.  Determine the hostile ones in time and you might survive. Some attack solo, others in packs. How cool is that?The world has many biomes, sea ,grasslands ,desert, forests and canyons. All beautifully constructed.The musical score is wonderful and is still being added to as is other game content.As is I am 50 hours into the game and have experienced no bugs. It is a joy to play.The characters are well animated and you can create your own at start. It appears that more features will be added to the character creation in the future.This game seems to have a little of everything, survival on a strange and beautiful world, a mysterios alien race, ruins, hostile tribals, discord within your own ranks between the earthlings and martian components.With more content coming every month I can't wait to see what is up next. You could spend hours just in the creation section building and awesome tank or helicopter to meet your own design standards.  Later import it in game and have your character climb on board and travel in style to any point in the game,The game doesen't hand hold you so you get to learn and explore and create as in a real world experience. There are small tutorials that give you the basics and fire the imagination,There is even a map that you can mark your building sites on, or locations of minerals you have located etc.There are tools for every job, shovels, picks, axes, swords, shields, guns, bows, laser guns, armour. This means you canplay the game as a medieval warrior or as a highly specialized space traveller with all the gadgets or somewhere in between.This game IMO was the best buy I have made in years.  A masterpice of fun and imagination.Hats off to the developers for such a polished and entertaining product.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Planet Explorers is nowhere near complete, it is after all, an Alpha. With that consideration in mind, this has the potential to be an amazing game. The only problems I've noticed are that the grass and shadow textures cause all sorts of lag problems, but this can be easily fixed by turning those textures off. The other being how user friendly it is. It is really not very user friendly. There is no real tutorial, figuring out how to get stuff into the game that you made in creation mode can take awhile, and the combat system is a little odd. Keeping in mind that this is in alpha, and it is nowhere near done, I'd say that most of these problems can be fixed, and I am sure they will be even better than I could imagine in time. This game is kinda like minecraft in space, so that's pretty awesome. I also love that there is character interaction, and that the interaction will only get better. Overall, I would reccommend this game strongly. It isn't great yet, but I know it will be.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I highly recommend this game. It's quite annoying at times, but the building possibilities and systems for building allow for endlass expansion and imagination, higher than that of Minecraft. While Minecraft is a rather frowned upon game, you can't help but to admit the possibilities of that game, as it is a very profitable sandbox. Planet Explorers is not like Minecraft in any other way than the limitless life span that the game can provide. You are able to make your own custom shield, sword or even rifle. You can construct your own vehicles, whether that be a boat, car or even a plane. You can build a castle. A colony. A city. Anything you can think of.There are three modes:Adventure, story and a mode similar to creative.In Adventure mode, you spawn in a colony and are surrounded by friendly people and many shopkeepers that inhabit the colony. You begin with nothing but clothes and a small knife, which most people in the colony are carrying. You also start of with quite a few revival shots, which are require to get up out on the battlefield to continue the fight. If you run out, don't worry. You will just spawn back at the colony.In Story mode, you start as a colonist who crashed in his ship and must save the person with you that has also survived. The planet is a foreign place, teaming with life. Your journey will take you through countless biomes and you will encounter many different creatures, friendly and aggressive. In Creative mode, it is as the title suggests. You travel the planet sculpting and constructing upon it to your hearts desire with no fear of losing it to those wretched aliens. The possibilities are endless in Planet Explorers.Pick it up now on sale, support the developer TODAY and grab a copy. Add me if you want to play some multiplayer or if you have any questions about the game before/after purchase.Thank you for reading.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm impressed. This indie game has accomplished far more and to a much better degree than alot of AAA titles I've played. I suggest picking it up and here's why:The AI pathfinding is wonderful. A follower only got stuck once and that's because I was trying to build the bridge as we were walking over it and I accidently built ontop of him. So chalk that up to my fault.Speaking of building I must say this is one of the nicest system I've seen. My only complaint is that I can't make slopes at any angle that I want, but I haven't fully examined the builder so I could've just missed it.The voxel system creates one of the best mining systems that smoothly change the terrain as you dig and mine for minerals.The item/vehicle creation is very nice and adds your own touch to the game.HOWEVER there are some negative point, but these might be solved as time goes on:The ranged weapons feel inaccurate. Yes you point and shoot and it hits the target, but the pistols feel like the rifles and it all seems the same.Some claim that the melee combat is like Monster Hunter, but I disagree. You can't specifically mess up a monster's leg or wings. On top of that I haven't found a way to dodge yet so it's been a contest of who can hit harder.There's no way to sort through the crafting menu. it's alphabetical, but if you forget that what you want is the "portible medkit" and not the "small medkit"(which I don't think there is one) then you can make the mistake of thinking you can't craft any small healing itemsDespite these complaints I like this game as is and the proposed additions can hopefully only make it better.EDIT: Upon review in the upper center of the replicator menu there is a way to sort out scripts. I found that it isn't a user friendly as other sorting systems, butit does exist and makes things simpler to a degree. Thank you to Thariorn for pointing this out to me.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edit: Updated to the 0.86 update.While this game is early access and there is still a bit the developers are working on the Single Player Story Mode is so well developed, expansive, and completed at this point in time that it seems a lot better than some "completed" games I have played.  The work they have put into it has won me over and I really look forward to seeing them finish the game.Admittedly it is early access and is not perfect.  Some quests are a bit glitchy and followers occasionally get stuck.I have not played multiplayer so do not have feedback on it.  I have played Story mode extensively (lots of solo exploration and have began working on my first settlement) and a bit of adventure mode.Since my original review the developers have worked on the adventure mode world generation as well as added new plants and animals.  The last adventure world I played was gorgeous and really made me want to explore it.Pros:Huge and developed story modeStory mode is a great tutorial on how the game works and all its ins and outsCan build your own vehicles and use them in gameVery playable for an Early access gameActive Development (some of the cons in my original review have been fixed or updated and there have been other additional features)Cons:Minor Bugs (it is Early Access and the bugs usually are minor)Creation UI could be cleanerClothing creation recipies are gender specific so you might end up creating items you can not use if you are not careful

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								You start crash landed on an uninhabited planet with nothing. In the first hour you dig and find doctor bro. 2nd hour he gives you blueprints to a sword, pickaxe, things like that, 3rd hour you spend mining a bunch of ore for a lady who wants you to build some turret to protect yourself from the mostly nonhostile wildlife, and a gun, which can be used to kill the nohostile wildlife. Then you learn to make your own guns. At this point I took a sidestep from the quests, and decided to settle on this planet like my forefathers settled 'Merica, by killing everything in sight. A little down the road I find that the planet is in fact inhabited by intelligent life, and I kill them too, because 'Merica. 10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've really only scratched the surface with about 20 hours in at this point,  but so far Planet Explorers is one of the best building (voxel) and adventure games I've had the joy of playing.   There are lots of elements of other games in here, and I think this game is going in a great direction.  Before you get into specifics if you're wondering if this game is playable and worth an early access purchase:   YES this game is completely playable,  its fun, it has a lot of stuff for you to do, and is one of the best sandboxes I've ever played.That being said here are some points I've noticed so far.The graphics are pretty good, and it runs like a dream on my (somewhat) aging laptop.  Performace is 25 FPS easy even on high load.  I've only played the adventure mode,  but there are some quests - most of them pretty basic.  Collect and kill mostly.The animals seem to be fairly varied,  as well as the attacks they do.The crafting is really great,  though the creation system could use a slightly better tutorial.  In fact most things could use a better tutorial -- but this is an early access game.  There is probably a lot more I can go into detail about,  though I haven't tried the multiplayer yet, but plan on it soon.  I can't wait for the next update.

As in real life you have to survive and try to get off planet or at least hook up with others.  In order to do this you mine materials, grow food, build habitations,forts,base camps,even villages.You create tools,weapons,machines,ATVs, aircraft etc. You hunt animals for meat which is also a currency, and harvest plants for mediciane. You scan the earth for minable resources.Some of the local fauna are passive some aggressive and you need to be alert and armed where ever you go. This adds a feeling of danger and realness to the game. As it would be in real life you learn about the planet through exploration, about its creatures through study and careful approach. All have there own biorythms.  Determine the hostile ones in time and you might survive. Some attack solo, others in packs. How cool is that?The world has many biomes, sea ,grasslands ,desert, forests and canyons. All beautifully constructed.The musical score is wonderful and is still being added to as is other game content.As is I am 50 hours into the game and have experienced no bugs. It is a joy to play.The characters are well animated and you can create your own at start. It appears that more features will be added to the character creation in the future.This game seems to have a little of everything, survival on a strange and beautiful world, a mysterios alien race, ruins, hostile tribals, discord within your own ranks between the earthlings and martian components.With more content coming every month I can't wait to see what is up next. You could spend hours just in the creation section building and awesome tank or helicopter to meet your own design standards.  Later import it in game and have your character climb on board and travel in style to any point in the game,The game doesen't hand hold you so you get to learn and explore and create as in a real world experience. There are small tutorials that give you the basics and fire the imagination,There is even a map that you can mark your building sites on, or locations of minerals you have located etc.There are tools for every job, shovels, picks, axes, swords, shields, guns, bows, laser guns, armour. This means you canplay the game as a medieval warrior or as a highly specialized space traveller with all the gadgets or somewhere in between.This game IMO was the best buy I have made in years.  A masterpice of fun and imagination.Hats off to the developers for such a polished and entertaining product.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Planet Explorers is nowhere near complete, it is after all, an Alpha. With that consideration in mind, this has the potential to be an amazing game. The only problems I've noticed are that the grass and shadow textures cause all sorts of lag problems, but this can be easily fixed by turning those textures off. The other being how user friendly it is. It is really not very user friendly. There is no real tutorial, figuring out how to get stuff into the game that you made in creation mode can take awhile, and the combat system is a little odd. Keeping in mind that this is in alpha, and it is nowhere near done, I'd say that most of these problems can be fixed, and I am sure they will be even better than I could imagine in time. This game is kinda like minecraft in space, so that's pretty awesome. I also love that there is character interaction, and that the interaction will only get better. Overall, I would reccommend this game strongly. It isn't great yet, but I know it will be.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												If any of the following appeals to you, then get this game - if any annoys you, then I guess don't get it? - Huge planet to explore with interesting fauna and flora- A story that is interesting (so far, not finished yet) and works with the open world survival crafting game- Vehicles - land, air, sea - and you can very freely create your own from scratch - flying around in your own helicopter is pretty cool- Build colonies and have your slaves... eh, colonists, work for you!- Build monorails across the world that drive along lines you create on a schedule (seriously cool)- Progression á la Minecraft from wooden, over iron, to diamond (really weird but it kinda works)I have Kickstarted this game way back and been skeptical at first since the development took very long and it was very clunky and buggy at first - but it's a great game now and I'm glad to have it.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a very fun game, and feels very complete despite being in Early Access.  A few little bugs here and there don't stop you from having heaps of fun with this one.  Highly recommended if you are into the explore/build/survival genre.The only bad things I can think of is the music score of the grasslands area which can get a little repetitive after a while.  Multiplay is also bit iffy (we could not get our map saved if we both logged off) but I am confident that will be fixed; the devs are quite engaging with the community. (and the music, you can turn off :p)Now the good things, I can think of many.  You can explore some gorgeous locations, the main story line is quite engaging and breadcrumbs your way nicely through the world, the crafting/building is really fun; ISO designing can be a little clunky at first until you learn the design tools, once you do you'll never stop as it's that addictive!This is one of those few Early Access games that make the whole Early Access "thing" worth it.

Early Access Review
								Amazing game and hard to believe this is Early Access! Updates come regularly and well worth getting into this!-update-This was originally a review made back shortly after its release to Steam. I have no idea why it says that it was written in May of this year. Steam Glitch...Please remember, this game is NOT final. There are some things in the game that the Devs have said in the past will likely NOT be in the final game. Lately (May period of 2015) the communication from the Devs have slowed down with delays of their latest release but don't sweat it. They have been giving us regular updates of the progress to this release even if it isn't very wordy. It has been enough to let us know they haven't abandoned this like some are thinking. TOO much effort in the past has been shown to prove this is a project they will see until it is finished. No, contrary to Gully's belief I am not paid in any way to say any of this. This is simply how I feel about this game. Well written, regular updates (and have been), Devs have been giving communication updates even if they are brief of what is going on.The Forums here are not the best to find answers and such. Go to Pathea's website and to their community forums. There you will find basic help in the general section, advanced help in the ISO creation and sharing section, Bug reports (remember this is EARLY ACCESS not even BETA) where you can and PLEASE DO report any bugs or add to any reports of bugs you have so it helps them track down the complex bugs, and simply other unrelated chat as well. The Devs don't often respond in the forums but it has been proven they do read them as some changes in the game came from the suggestion forums and simply discussions between groups of players in the general chat.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								*This review is based off an older version, around .72 alpha buildFirst off. Let me start with performance.I do not lag on this game on any settings and with my computer underclocked. And it still looks wonderful.Let me restate that,.... Space Engineers(on any world older than a day), Minecraft(for most people), 7 days to die, + any other game you can think of that is voxel based..... Planet Explorers not only looks better, but handles better.Nuff said.Music/sound: needs more variety if they are still on the same tracks as the last version I played. But for what they do have, the music is refreshing and fits right in. It is not intrusive at all. Sound had wierd glitches here and there, but stuff that was actively getting fixed and nothing that really stood out.animation/combat: I am clumping these two together for a reason,... they are closely tied for the trouble parts. Overall its pretty good, both the animation and the combat. But something about combat makes me feel more like I am aiming for hit boxes and not an actual entity. I do not like this in the slightest, so even tho I would like to be a melee combatant, I feel forced into ranged combat because of this.*I believe theres been some changes to combat that may effect my opinion on this, I will change my review to reflect more recent versions as I play them*Scenery: Yes, this one warrants its own section. The landscape of Planet Explorers is beautiful. And the variety of foliage(trees, grass, bushes, flowers) is beyond what any other game I have played has attemptedCreatures: Again, something that I might not have commented on in any other game... Planet Explorers creature deserve a mention. The variety and detail put into the creatures is astonishing. And they keep adding more! I did 3 'Main' playthroughs of the storymode for this game before the last version- and EVERY time there was more creatures that I hadnt seen before! Someone in their department is pumping them out, and I am loving it!Story: The story is actually pretty good if you pay attension to what is going on(i.e. dont skip thru text)The presentation certainly is not winning any awards, but as far as I am concerned, it doesn't have to. What is nice here is that in storymode(singleplayer), the story is not shoved down your throat. You are free to pursue the story, or do your own thing.Survival Aspect: This is a survival game after all, and thats what most of us(or at least me) come to do. And I must say that on the version I played, I wasnt as impressed as I hoped. It felt like survival was optional, and that should never be the case in a survival game. I don't know if that makes any sense, but... not hardcore enough for me? maybe.Good news is I heard there is an editor thing planned that from what details I heard, will definately be able to accomidate anything I feel is missing here.Developers: This one is of special note. I have never before PE seen a head of development for a game interact with the community, on a near daily basis. Furthermore, in the time I spent observing and partaking in the forums I have not seen so much straightforwardness and honestly from developers. This is both commendable and heartwarming. I will not provide examples, as they stand on the forums for all to see.Also, it is easy to tell these developers actually care about their game.Summary: It's a great game and only getting better,... I couldn't recommend it more. If still in doubt, try out the demo. I insist! Do the storymode first... the other modes are farther behind and don't accurately represent what the dev's are trying to accomplish.**Note: I will update this review as I play newer versions.... anything here will likely change for the better.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Looking at this game from the perspective of a single player sci-fi campaign, it's looking worth the money. Now that the game has had a few iterations in the beta developement phase, the story mode seems far more playable and less buggy. From what they've said in their update notes, I'd venture to say the story mode is more or less finished. May still be a few problems to work out with their Intro/Tutorial though.I have had this game for about a year and I've played a bit in the Multi-Player Adventure mode. In the past there wasn't much progression to the Adventure story, but it seems that they have plans to change that. They had done something with their random terrain generator that created lots of ugly ridges in the landscape, which are very difficult to navigate with wheeled vehicles. I need to take another look at Adventure mode, but I'm waiting on further updates. So at this moment I can't really comment on their random generated Adventure mode.I feel that the interface and control setup takes a bit of getting used to, but once you get the hang of the controls it's pretty easy to play the game. I'm not well skilled at using 3D modeling software tools, but it's really not too difficult to learn the basics of the Creation tool in order to quickly create simple vehicles. Very elaborate designs are possible, and I've seen many examples of player created ISO's for this game. I do expect that there will be some Steam Workshop content available in the future.Altogether I think that Planet Explorers is shaping up as a good buy.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game could use some work but aside from the occasional bugs and glitches, It's not that bad for an early access game. I mean HECK! I'd go ahead and say that this game is BRILLIANT for an early access game!The single-player mode is fun but it does take a long time to get around so I recommend getting some supplies fast and building a vehicle if you want to explore.The Co-Op is in a sense more fun than single player but is a little glitchier than the forementioned.Honestly I had more fun just exploring and finding all the wierd aliens I could! My favourite landscape or biome would need to be the the canyon area but all the different landscapes combine well and feel quite natural; The creatures on the otherhand are by far my favourite aspect of the game!The amount of animals is amazing, with the sizes ranging from the tiny Vulpes Haola to the the enormous Testudo Mariturtle.The best ai would probably be the unnamed cliff lizard thing in the canyon biome, It took me Four hours to find just one and even the the ai got the best of me....

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Problem with the Linux client, in case your character instantly dies when entering the world, and instantly dies again after revive, put this in startup options (without the quotes):"LC_ALL=en_US.utf8 %command%"It turns out there is no OpenCL hardware support for Mac and Linux Ubuntu(*), which means really terrible performance unfortunately.(*) Apparently due to broken nvidia 331 proprietary driver. In order to fix this, you might have some luck with this approach (in the order mentioned below):- apt-get install nvidia-cuda-toolkit- apt-get install ocl-icd-opencl-dev- reboot- revert to "legacy 304 proprietary driver" from nvidia- rebootUse at your own risk, the driver is outdated and might break other games, your cat might choke and the antichrist make his appearance. If it does work and none of the above happens, it does run very well.Kinda on the fence with this one due to the many hoops I had to jump to get it to run properly, still thumbs up, as it is a beautiful game and kinda sticks out of the whole sandbox crafting openworld somewhatminecraftish crowd.Now, the terrain (and terrain manipulation) in this one is really well done, is is actually quite fun digging a cave and putting stuff in there.So are the characters, they have a very unique touch to them.The crafting also appears to be a rather unique approach, havent had time to check it out in-depth yet though.

Posted: May 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								There's always the impulse to compare it to certain other sandbox games... but I don't know how. Planet Explorers plays like an RPG, crafting game, exploration, adventure, even a 3D modelling program!* It's like Elements: You start with initial resources like plants and minerals, and can craft new technologies & accessories.* It's like an RPG: Beautiful open world, small & large enemies, Obtain missions by talking to NPC's, some of which can join your party and eventually your colony (city)! They will fight with you & you can equip them with weapons, armors, items, or just give them stuff to carry.* It's a sandbox: make tools to help you dig out the world. Search for ore deposits using your 3D scanner then use them to construct just about anything! (not player-designed clothing)* It's 3D modelling software: Construct swords, shields, guns, land/sea/air vehicles, or just decoration objects like stairs, utilities, household, really anything you can think of!Custom models are inserted into the game like this: If you have the resources required to build it, they will automatically be removed from your inventory and the object will appear. You can interact with it or pick it up anytime that you are next to it. An 'approved' build that has been picked up may be reused until it is destroyed; once it's built, it's built.I have spent over 10 hours on Story mode so far and I have only just built my first car. I have leather armor, sword & shield, bow & rifle. My 2 followers have Steel armor & swords; they 'tank' while I shoot. I have barely explored the south-central part of the island. There are videos of immense constructs and firepower, enemies and adventure. I have only barely begun, and I am very much addicted :).

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								NOTE:  Review will change if they fix things.  However, I'm writing this review because things have been too rough and unfinished for too long.  Especially the game breaking bug for if you have anything plugged in other than keyboard + mouse.------------------------------Extremely, *extremely* buggy, even for an early access title.If you have any controller plugged in, or use vJoy or any head tracking, you have to disable them from the device manager before you load up the game.  There are no options to disable controllers or joysitcks ingame at this time.If you don't disable your peripherals, the camera will bug out and spin around your characters feet, making the game unplayable.If you DO disable them and try to generate a world to play in, the world is very buggy.  Your character can run through objects in the starting village, and can run up and down sheer cliffs.It doesn't feel like a sandbox game like Minecraft or Kerbal Space Program.  It feels like a very, very shoddy MMORPG that you play on your own.  Especially the combat system.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								When I first bought and played Planet Explorers over 2 years ago, I loved it and couldn't wait to see how it evolved.All this time later and the A09 update they have talked baout for so long finally happens, so I give it another 3 weeks and several updates to make sure things are ironed out okay before going back. Its terrible. Single player is worse than it was 2 years ago in some way and only marginally better in other ways, and trying to play any mode with a friend is still the buggy waste of time it was 2 years ago.The newly added co-op story mode I was excited to finally play with a friend was too broken to play too. At this point, there are simply lots of better games to choose from that are actually going somehwere. Planet explorers has taken FAR too long to do far too little, and at this point it shouldnt cost what it does anymore. Its a real shame, but I don't see this game ever being done. if it ever is though, it won't even matter anymore.Too little too late. Its a shame the game still has the misleading mostly positive reviews just because of the great reception it got years ago. Most of those should be negative now but I believe those players that had hope then gave up long ago and never even came back to say so.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I know this is early access and so I will treat it as such in my review.  Right now I cannot recommend this to all but the most die hard EA players that must try everything before they are released.  I'll be brief as I can.  There are some positives about this game but in a nutshell it's not ready yet for me to give it a full thumbs up.  Wish Steam had a way to give 1 to 5 stars.  If this were a star rating I'd give it a 3 for now. It seems like it has a lot of potential.  The graphics, while a bit simple, are attractive enough, in a cute, and cartoony way.  If that look is something that appeals to you it will fit in just fine.  I don't mind that aspect but just pointing that out.  Which brings me to the first downside.  with the simplified graphics, i don't understand with a very capable gaming computer like I have, why it has stutter, quite frequently.  I would say every 20 to 30 seconds the game stutters for a moment and although it's not game breaking it is quite annoying.  The positives from my prior game plays (where I played quite a bit more time back weeks ago) I like:  the gathering, build mode and craft-heaviness of the game at least early on.  The combat could use some polish along with the gathering aspects.  The tutorial or beginning doesn't tell you much about how to do things and although I don't want hand holding for every little thing, it would be nice for the basics like how to open the replicator.  Basics like this, I know you can find in help but I will venture to guess that most players don't like to spend their early minutes in a game looking up how to do all the basic stuff.  Again, this game could be good once all details are worked out, and I will keep an eye out but for now I cannot recommend it.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								-NOTE: This review is for a game in alpha!Very unique game with tons of creative ideas, but as it is in alpha, these ideas lack a lot of flare, and are very underdeveloped. In fact, all the game's ideas (not to mention the whole game itself) is packed to the brim with bugs and errors. The story mode is something I consider awful. The voice acting for all NPC's and keystory characters is annoying, and really feels like something you'd find at a high school acting club. The missions are all tedious, and rarely go beyond the MMORPG tropes of "kill X of Y" or "Collect X of Y". This is especially disheartening considering this is a singleplayer storyline, and yet it lacks anything to really intrigue me for longer than an hour. The multiplayer is glitchy as hell. Sometimes I'd be able to join a server, but most of the time this wouldn't be the case. Even when hosting my own server, something I've had a lot of experience with, the connection is very unreliable, working around 50% of the time. Now I'm positive this isn't an error on my end, as I actually have a personal server in my home, have hosted private servers for numerous games, and followed the game dev's official server setup instructions to the letter.... twice. Even if I am able to connect to a server, be it my own or someone elses, in multiplayer, there is no way to control where you spawn, meaning you and your friends will be in entirely different villages and required to shlepp around until you find each other making it very, very tedious. The create mode is the true selling point of this game. The create mode is incredibly easy to use, and almost reminds me of a dumbed down version of Solidworks, a 3D modeling program I used to use quite a lot. That being said, it is still very unrefined and lacks a lot of the flare to create anything more than some basic cars or guns without spending hours in it. There are so many tools missing from the overall creation experience, that many things are so complex to create in this 3D modeling software. This is extremely frustrating since I know that I could easily make a lot of this stuff using the vastly more advanced tools of something like Solidworks, or hell, even the Microsoft 3D modeling software. Also, there is no options for zooming besides using a mouse wheel which is annoying since I'm so used to modeling with a trackpad. This game does have a lot of potential for sure, and I will be looking at it again in beta and the final version, but as it stands right now I couldn't reccomend this at all. If I had to give this game a score, which I probably shouldn't given it's not even in beta, I'd have to give it a 4/10. Avoid this game like the expensive plague. Also, a word of advice to all "early release" developers. Please sell your alpha games at a discount. Usually you have to pay people to play such glitchy monstrosities, and it's something I deeply regret that I paid full retail for this junk heap.EDIT: Grammar corrections.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								This was a waste of money. I have liked the idea of this game for quite a long time.  The fact that its still not finished and that i cannot play on a LAN with my friend without an internet connection have made me change my review from a positive to a negative.  Im sick and tired, as a paying customer, to make sacrifices in the name of DRM.  I have a detached garage with no internet access that I use for LAN parties.  The trend is these days is to require internet access so that all players have a valid copy.  I understand the desire to get paid for hard work, however, this only punishes paying customers.  For example, Diablo 3 requires an internet connection for the offline single player campaign.  Horribly intrusive for the paying customer hoping to play on the go, but a hacked version was released on♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥within hours of the release of the game that didn't require an active internet connection.  The pirates actually got MORE playability on this one.  I will not dig a 200 ft trench to install lan cable to my garage, nor will i try to get a stable wireless connection to transmit that far.  I will simply sulk, leave bad reviews and do better research before I buy a game.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Having played the free earlier alpha on their website I was certainly impressed enough to buy it to play the latest versions.  There are some changes such as the controls (now you can set your own keys to use), graphical changes and extra modes but the core game hasn't been tampered with which even at this early stage is more playable than some full releases.A sci-fi RPG game with mining and crafting parts but it's not Minecraft so don't come into this thinking you'll be doing the same thing as you were in Minecraft.  For one thing the mining is a bit clumsier and slower.  The crafting side is more powerful but does have a bit of a learning curve to get to grips with in the creation mode where you'll be building vehicles and buildings blueprints.Try the demo first before buying but if you give it a chance you'll probably be smitten.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've been saying for a while that my perfect game would be a cross between Skyrim and Minecraft:  I want big, beautiful graphics, quests and plenty of monsters to kill, and an open world I can dig up in 3D to build my house brick-by-brick.  And I have to say that so far Planet Explorers is already coming pretty close!  I love the planet's megafauna and that there's a predator/prey system in place.  I love that plants apparently have a life cycle.  And the premise of the story is just fantastic.  (Did I mention how much I love that a sandbox game has an actual story?)And there's a Thing editor.  Vehicles, swords, shields, random arts and crafts:  THINGS.  I honestly didn't expect to like it, because I'm not what you'd call an architect, or an engineer.  And then I built this car.  It was an awful car, but the next one I built was twice as awesome in half the time.  And then I built a helicopter.  A helicopter, okay?  It was magic.  (Okay, it was awful.  But the ability to make a helicopter?  THAT was magic.)Yes, the game still has its issues; it's in alpha after all, so that's to be expected.  In A0.82, farming is a little iffy (I suggest you start with a 5x5 plot of non-organic and work your way up from there) and I've had some crashing problems, but the answer to this is so simple I've actually played through until there are no more quests at present to play, my base is complete, and I have all the things.  In a nutshell:  save religiously.  Once I got out of the habit of relying on autosave, I was golden.Tl;dr:  this is an awesome game for many, many reasons, only requiring a modicum of patience, and will only get better.

								Having played the free earlier alpha on their website I was certainly impressed enough to buy it to play the latest versions.  There are some changes such as the controls (now you can set your own keys to use), graphical changes and extra modes but the core game hasn't been tampered with which even at this early stage is more playable than some full releases.A sci-fi RPG game with mining and crafting parts but it's not Minecraft so don't come into this thinking you'll be doing the same thing as you were in Minecraft. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								-NOTE: This review is for a game in alpha!Very unique game with tons of creative ideas, but as it is in alpha, these ideas lack a lot of flare, and are very underdeveloped. In fact, all the game's ideas (not to mention the whole game itself) is packed to the brim with bugs and errors. The story mode is something I consider awful. The voice acting for all NPC's and keystory characters is annoying, and really feels like something you'd find at a high school acting club. The missions are all tedious, and rarely go beyond the MMORPG tropes of "kill X of Y" or "Collect X of Y". This is especially disheartening considering this is a singleplayer storyline, and yet it lacks anything to really intrigue me for longer than an hour. The multiplayer is glitchy as hell. Sometimes I'd be able to join a server, but most of the time this wouldn't be the case. Even when hosting my own server, something I've had a lot of experience with, the connection is very unreliable, working around 50% of the time. Now I'm positive this isn't an error on my end, as I actually have a personal server in my home, have hosted private servers for numerous games, and followed the game dev's official server setup instructions to the letter.... twice. Even if I am able to connect to a server, be it my own or someone elses, in multiplayer, there is no way to control where you spawn, meaning you and your friends will be in entirely different villages and required to shlepp around until you find each other making it very, very tedious. The create mode is the true selling point of this game. The create mode is incredibly easy to use, and almost reminds me of a dumbed down version of Solidworks, a 3D modeling program I used to use quite a lot. That being said, it is still very unrefined and lacks a lot of the flare to create anything more than some basic cars or guns without spending hours in it. There are so many tools missing from the overall creation experience, that many things are so complex to create in this 3D modeling software. This is extremely frustrating since I know that I could easily make a lot of this stuff using the vastly more advanced tools of something like Solidworks, or hell, even the Microsoft 3D modeling software. Also, there is no options for zooming besides using a mouse wheel which is annoying since I'm so used to modeling with a trackpad. This game does have a lot of potential for sure, and I will be looking at it again in beta and the final version, but as it stands right now I couldn't reccomend this at all. If I had to give this game a score, which I probably shouldn't given it's not even in beta, I'd have to give it a 4/10. Avoid this game like the expensive plague. Also, a word of advice to all "early release" developers. Please sell your alpha games at a discount. Usually you have to pay people to play such glitchy monstrosities, and it's something I deeply regret that I paid full retail for this junk heap.EDIT: Grammar corrections.

								To be honest I was starting to avoid these early access games like a virus, I mean where is the motivation to finnish a game, when you have already been paid for it, and even though Steam are pretty awesome, they just dont lay down any rules for actually finishing what they started, 10% of my library is early access and I know that 90% of them are going nowhere.Planet explorers is another rip off of minecraft, but compared to other early access games it looks great, and the building is new and innovative, the controls (still a tiny bit glitchy) are nice and the world is massive, with loads of well designed alien animals and plenty of game modes.I could go on and on, but I wont, at the end of the day for the price of about 20 euro (i think thats what i paid) its a bargain, dont expect next gen graphics (but they are suprisingly good for early access) and enjoy!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Planet Explorers is to Space Engineers what Starbound is to Terraria.  More invironments, more things to do, and more work required by the designers.  Both PE and SE have volumetric destructible environments and player-built square blocks everywhere, which can be destroyed easily by enemies.  But PE tries to have a whole Story (actually a series of linked quests), AI enemies and helpers, and a world-based environment as opposed to asteroids.  Planet Explorers also tries to have you build up a colony.  It also channels a bit of the MMO Calypso, but with a colony that is just starting, rather than well underway.Regards A0.7.5.2:It is Alpha, and Unity based.  Highest graphical settings on OpenGL are not recommended, but DirctX is fine so far.  There is little optimisation as yet, and multiplayer parties should stay together as digging info is not correctly remembered by all clients if they are far apart.  But there is a lot of expectation, and a playable game as it stands.  I just hope that when they say the version number, (currently A0.752, or in the game 0.7.5.2) that they don't stop when the second part reaches 10.  Most basics are there, and now they need QA and more additional stuff regards the world size and colonies.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								This was a waste of money. I have liked the idea of this game for quite a long time.  The fact that its still not finished and that i cannot play on a LAN with my friend without an internet connection have made me change my review from a positive to a negative.  Im sick and tired, as a paying customer, to make sacrifices in the name of DRM.  I have a detached garage with no internet access that I use for LAN parties.  The trend is these days is to require internet access so that all players have a valid copy.  I understand the desire to get paid for hard work, however, this only punishes paying customers.  For example, Diablo 3 requires an internet connection for the offline single player campaign.  Horribly intrusive for the paying customer hoping to play on the go, but a hacked version was released on♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥within hours of the release of the game that didn't require an active internet connection.  The pirates actually got MORE playability on this one.  I will not dig a 200 ft trench to install lan cable to my garage, nor will i try to get a stable wireless connection to transmit that far.  I will simply sulk, leave bad reviews and do better research before I buy a game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game shows alot of potential! The open world, combined with random seed generation is always a great choice for RPG's.If you are buying this game you should be aware that it obviously according to the big blue box is in alpha. So don't expect it to be perfect. For a game in alpha it runs suprisingly smooth and can accomodate lower graphic settings if your computer can't handle the highest.  The gameplay is dynamic and the creatures are all very interesting and seem to have their own movesets. Due to the item and vehicle creation system you can spend hours messing about with your friends creating various different cars and buildings. The sandbox terrain is awesome and allows you to build little hobbit holes away from the rest of the (alien dinosaurs?) 8/10 - needs bug improvement (low graphics and a fast car seem to allow you to glitch below the terrain) But this game shows so much potential and is definitely worth backing!

content:

								Well this game is still a work in progress so it does have the odd bug that shows up and that is pretty much the only problem with it. Report the bugs and the Devs will solve those problems for you very quickly.     Planet Explorers seems to be a group of ideas a Development Team has accumulated and assembled into a fantastic game. Having the ability to build your own vehicle and then import it into the game for your character to use once you have the resources is so easy and fun to do and the creature AI is one that a lot of other games need. Being attacked by a pack of carnivores and then watching the survivors flee once they realise you are hard to kill, or not being attacked until they see you adds a new level to the gameplay. Watching carnivores hunt other animals also adds to it. The are a large number of elements in this game and  they are not all there just to make the game difficult for you to play but they do make for a real adventure.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								UPDATE: I originally reviewed this game in 2014 and that review is below. This game was fantastic. After revisiting the game today I can honestly say it has gotten much much worse over the last two years. To be fair, I did not play the story mode today but the adventure mode which was always my favorite part of the game before is now completely shot. I can't tell you why it's gone wrong, but I can tell you how.1. In-game sound is GONE. There's a random click here and there but ZERO environmental effects or music or anything like that.2. Dialog is AWFUL. Seriously, talking to NPC's in the game is now worse than trying to read a cheap china-made fortune cookie... In chinese.3. Procedural terrain generator is BROKEN. I'm talking completely random giant divots in the ground worse than the potholes on a washed out backcountry road I didn't dare build anything with wheels to try to drive around.4. Framerates have gone straight into the crapper. Somehow, despite adding 12 GB of RAM and upgrading to a much beefier video card since my original review, my framerates are about HALF what they were before.This seems like a classic case of a game being fixed until they broke it. I couldn't even play for an hour before I felt compelled to quit. Any longer and I would probably have gouged my own eyes out. I honestly hope they can fix this game, because it was SO GOOD before. I'll revisit this review at some point in the future and I'd REALLY like to be able to give it a thumbs-up again... But in the current state of the game, I simply can't recommend it. Not anymore. Sorry Pathea... But PLEASE fix this awful mess.Original Review:Get off the fence and buy it. It's totally worth every penny, even now in early access. There are some bugs, but nothing game-breaking, and the playability and amount of content is fantastic. At this point in development it's easy to forget it's still in alpha. Being able to easily create, use, and share equipment and vehicles alone makes it worth it.If you like sandbox games and a sci-fi, survival, or fantasy setting you will love this game. I keep coming back and the dev team keeps impressing me. You can spend hours just hunting creatures, or you can spend hours playing through the story, or you can spend hours designing that next badass sandrail or VTOL. The more you put into the game, the more you'll get out of it. Now buy it and try it. You'll see.One caveat... Read the required system specs before you buy it. They're not BSing. If you can't meet those specs this game will barely run if at all. Not kidding. If you can't get a decent framerate you're going to have a very hard time with this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Incredible game, just incredible. I am currently as of writing this only six hours into the story mode, but wow. The graphics are great, it is very well optimized(at least SP, again have not tried online at all),the combat isnt amazing but is still fun,there are ALOT of creatures/aliens that all have different behavioral patterns(i.e. there is a stegosaurous looking guy that travels in packs)that mesh very well togther. The colony feature is also something to shout about. It basically allows you to recruit your fellow colonists once you do some quests for them. This makes hunting in single player much more entertaining and immersive, while adding more strategy as your colonists will only have what you equip them with, including healing items and ammo.Last but certainly not least is the crafting system. On its surface, it appears much like anyother survival crafting(using resources harvested from the world) to create things like wood pickaxe,copper pickaxe ect. However, there is a crafting editor where you can make literally anything you want. For example, I saw a guy that made a laser pistol that looked just like a X-wing,again that was a hand held laser pistol. Anything from weapons, armor, robots, vehicles(land, air and sea) and more.Not only that but you can choose any kind of resource to make any of the parts from, changing the stats of whatever for example a gun made from refined steel will probally do more damage than wood or normal steel.So bottom line, if you are looking for a game that offers you the choice between complete freedom or more structured play style, do yourself a favor and pick this up.p.s.- do yourself a favor and watch a youtube video and not the store page ones, they honestly downplay how great this game really is.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								The world feels enormous, the NPCs feel like they're made of cardboard.  The animations are chunky, the landscape has white lines in it sometimes, but the sheer number of things you can make is incredible.  Unfortunately, the creator is really tricky to use for the time being.  I'm not sure it would be harder to use 3DSMax at this rate to make my first vehicle.  This is definitely in alpha.  There's no question about it.  A lot of the AI and animations has a lot of polishing left to do, the combat's hilariously clunky, and the 'storyline' isn't terribly well-balanced.  But that said, it's a fantastic start.  There's plenty to do, plenty to build, and lots of frightening spore-creator kinds of creatures to roam about and kill vicariously.  If you want a game that gives you enormous amounts of space and room for creativity, this is it.  All that aside, though, there's a hell of a lot you can do with building up your base and your armaments.  Shields and swords can be custom-designed with the voxel editor.  Buildings can be given lovely cornering and layouts, with plenty of accessories already avaioable for use.  The cars are just that perfect blend of controllable and completely bonkers to drive, making your bouts of ATVing hilarious, wonky, and yet not actually frustrating.  This game picks -way- up once you start getting into vehicles and colony control.  That said, to get the resources needed to get there, you're probably gonna have to look at the wiki.  There are very few veins of certain resources.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Note: I've only played singleplayerThe game itself is nice, the crafting aspect is deep, almost TOO deep (Not a bad thing, I just haven't gotten the hang of it) The map seems pretty huge. but that's okay, you can build vehicles (flying, land, and sea) to get around.The story is interesting, not like, game of the year "10/10 would bang" good, but it's interesting, you're apart of a group of people who are looking for a new home in the universe and you crash land on this planet, and now you're trying to find everyone, and it goes from there. The voice audio for some of the characters sounds muffled, kinda weird and kills the immersion. I'm assuming they have that on the radar to work on. The combat is cool, although (I could be wrong) but it doesn't seem like headshots matter when fighting creatures. not a big deal, but just something I noticed. You can have followers, that's neat, and they have skills / abilities that differ from follower to follower. You can have them stay put somewhere, follow you, etc. and you can set them to defensive, aggressive, and passive. You have to manage various types of ailments. Infection, injuries, etc. oh, and of course hunger. Don't eat too much though! there's a penalty for that. Pretty cool. Overall I love the game, I kept telling myself that I was going to go play something else, and next thing I knew I had been playing it all day and didn't want to stop so I could build that next thing, or finish this ONE quest, etc. I can't wait to see what they do next for this game, it's neat.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I thought I had reviewed this already... huh. Anyway this game is in development so there are some UI tweaks and bugs to fix but the core thing itself - is a thing of wonder. You start off wondering what the hell just happened and why the blaze you just crashed a spaceship and don't have any weapons other than, quite literally, a small plastic knife. Pretty soon you're collecting plants, digging, chopping trees, running to or from alien animals, doing busy-body work for various NPCs for 'recipes' for new things to make like armour or weapons or circuit boards.Then you find yourself making a cute little house somewhere and you've built yourself a little aircraft in the shape of something not safe for work, realised that doesn't fly well enough to even get off the ground without flipping upside down, so you then attempt to build something that is both hilarious and practical. You can sculpt a bow out of gold while your companions use lasers because arrows are cheap and then you find yourself on the run from bears that shoot actual fireballs until you realise you can totally just build a little tower to stand on like a boss while you plunk at them with arrows.Then you're building up a small colony and assigning jobs because you've been unofficially made Mayor and thus you build yourself the nicest home while your poor colonists get open space living with as many beds as you can cram into one big room and they're doing your farming for you now and fighting various random animals and running into the ocean shooting alien seagulls and every time you think "Okay this is everything now" it keeps getting bigger. So you make another bow in the shape of [censored] that can one shot giant space beetles and realise you haven't even explored the other biomes yet so you make a flying shopping trolley that puts any followers into the baby seat and trolley off to parts unknown. 11/10 would humiliate Rol again.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												This is almost a very good game.  It took installing it again to remember why I quit playing it.  So, drawbacks first and then what's so great about it.  Drawbacks:If you're not playing in the equivalent of creative mode, so that you have content, then you have two modes: story and adventure.  In story, there are timesinks as you gradually gain access to scripts that allow you to produce better and better items.  But by the time you have a thriving colony, there's nothing left to work toward except the end of the story.  If you play adventure mode, then you bypass all of the grinding because you begin with all scripts.  However, this renders the majority of scripts useless because you'll skip straight to the best items.  This is the better option for exploring and building a colony.  However, the drawback there is that you only get four NPCs and there's no guarantee that any of them will join your colony.  There are reportedly more NPCs out on the map, in many cases, very far from your starting point.  But the map is not infinite, which means that your progress is still capped.  Once you've built up your colony and recruted all the accessible NPCs on the map, there's nothing to work toward.  How to correct these drawbacks:Literally all it needs is a tech tree for story mode and new NPCs that join the map to be recruited in adventure mode.  The tech tree would allow the player to choose what to access first, rather than wander until NPCs with the necessary scripts are discovered.  It would still be a bit of a timesink, but the player would have more control over how that timesink is progressed through, and could prioritize goals.  As it is, later scripts are often found at the same time as earlier scripts, rendering even the explore-to-advance angle pointless (ie, finding the script for a copper bow at the same time as iron bow and pistol).  Having new NPCs wander onto adventure maps would allow for expansion of colonies to encompass the map, providing a long term, ongoing goal of expansion.  What makes this game great:I hate to use the word "potential" when it's so close to realizing that potential.  Imagine Rimworld with a RPG built on top of it, where you control a single character directly.  Imagine first person play in that game, with the ability to design custom items and structures to use and share with others.   Imagine skill trees for your colonists, vehicles, and diverse challenges on the map.  I'm clicking "Yes" that I recommend this game, but I do so with the wish that we could click a "Maybe" option.  The fact is that this game is very close to being something awesome, and at least where adventure mode is concerned, it would be very simple for the developers to realize its potential.  But as of this review, they haven't.  The result is that a rich game leaves you feeling empty, like it could have been so much more, and the simplicity of what it is missing tacks frustration onto that sentiment.Addendum:It may be possible to put something together in the World Editor that would alleviate the adventure mode problem.  Perhaps, for example, a map with enough NPCs that can be recruited to make it worth playing.  The first problem is, the DPI scaling for the World Editor is so horrendous that on a modern 4k screen, it can't even be used.  The second problem is that even World Editor maps are randomly generated, and editing terrain (along with practically all other functionality in the editor) is non-intuitive, slow, and frustrating.  All the reasons you can think of to use a World Editor, are reasons not to use it in this case.  I still think that this game can realize its potential, but I'm disappointed that it hasn't gotten there yet.  In this case, it appears that the developers begin with the assumption that people want to play the game, when instead they should stop and think about what would motivate people to play in the first place and then build on that.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a wonderful game and fulfilled all my expectations.  I highly recommend it, because as much fun as I've had with it now, it's only going to get better as the game comes closer and closer to exiting early access.  There are still some bugs to work out, but I wouldn't say they're a major hindrance to enjoying Planet Explorers.I played several hours of the campaign and a bit of the exploration mode.  The mining, crafting, gathering and cooking systems are very solid.  The 3D resource scanner system takes a lot of the guess work out of things, which is very welcome, and the inventory system isn't oppressive with encumberance or backpack limitations.  Upgrading gear between schematics and resource quality was very rewarding and interesting - eventually taking huge chunks of a mountain out at a time felt really good after plinking away at it with a low tier copper pickaxe.The combat has a lot of flexibility and is entirely gear dependent, and if you have the right minerals, you have the best gear.  The follower systems ensures very good balance for most situations.  Multiplayer was a blast, and buildin my own settement was very rewarding.  As was building my own vehicle from a blueprint starting with no template, only key parts.  The game's seeds are not impossibly large, and have a lot going on to the point where you'll never have to trudge for a long distance totally bored, unless you want to just to explore.  Very interesting wildlife designs and behaviors, lots of predator/prey ambient stuff going on that you can watch.  The giant antagonists are rightfully dangerous and intimidating, very challenging but not impossible to overcome with a solid team.I very much enjoy this game.  If I had to complain, I'd say that I wish there was more to the character customization, and some of the storyline quests have some annoying bugs, mostly relating to friendly AI behavior.  The game can be gorgeous in places, but only if you ignore some of the low res, constantly repeating ground textures.  Regardless, I still highly recommend Planet Explorers.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Who wouldn't recommend this game? o.o';Like for real..? Who wouldn't?.The game is great, and for a price of 22,99.. hell yeah.I've been playing the game for 44 hours so far, and I can't get enough.%Environment-The world itself, feels incredibly smooth. The leaves dancing around, as you walk through the forests.. just awesome.It sort of.. brings the place more to life. It's all about the little things :3And let's not forget the nature..They've done a really good job, since it's set on a different planet, many lightyears away; It'd only be logical to make a new type of nature, instead of the basic trees and flowers we see everywhere.Let's take one of the tree's as an example :D - The C which fell. <- apparently what I call it >:o.Like, it's literally a tree formed as a C, but with both ends in the ground; with a few branches sticking out here n there.I personally haven't seen that one before.And the awesome flowers which again doesn't seem like everyday flowers, but neither too fantasized..Some are quite huge and others are tiny; but they're all pretty well made.For an alpha release, this couldn't possibly get any better.%Characters & Customization-I'm all in for customization and eye candy.. I'm just that type of person.But in this case, it actually doesn't hit me as hard as in other games..The Character Creation System isn't too advanced(at the moment.)But you're still capable of giving your character a personality.Currently there is; -FEMALE-5 Female Face Types.15 Female Hairstyles.(+any colour) (not bad for an alpha, huh?)1 Female Voice.(no menu)1 Body Type. (Though you can colour your skin to almost any colour you want.)And an empty "Other" tab(wonder what'll be added here :D)-MALE-4 Male Face Types.11 Male Hairstyles.(+any colour)1 Male Voice.(no menu)1 Body Type. (colour applies here too of course.)And the "Other" Tab.-The characters aren't super HD looking in the Char Creator. But in the game itself, they're quite good looking.Plus with the visually shown armor types in-game, you won't need much more :).%Game Modes-For an alpha release, they sure have a lot for us to toy around with....The game currently has three -(+VS Mode online)- game modes in the alpha release;Story Mode (you follow the storyline + free roam..)Adventure(+ VS Mode online) Mode (open world free roaming, where you decide what to do)Build Mode (exactly what it sounds like..)I won't go indepth with the game modes themselves..Though I will say that my favorite mode, is Normal Adventure Mode(non-VS) online.%Creation System-This feature right here... FREAKISHLY AMAZING.It's like an in-game simple to use modelling program.So far it's possible to make:Swords.Pistols.Rifles.Small vehicles.Larger vehicles.Helicopters.VTOLs.Battleships(30x60x28 meters..'if i remember correctly..') (flying ones.. not a boat D:)And Tiny, Medium and Large Objects.And the best part of this feature? you can import your creations right into the game.Well, yes in singleplayer, you might say.. NOPE. The online multiplayer servers have an upload/import function, when you launch the creation system within them.All of the creations require their respective materials to be made though.Engines, metal, sword hilts.. fuel.... etc.All something you have to have in your inventory, before you're able to import your creations.Now, this feature is too big for me to indepth with.It's something you have to toy around with.%Minecraft Comparisons-Here we go.. another minecraft clone. Right? - Oh hell no!!#$@&^This epic piece of work deserves its own place in the spotlight.I don't get why every single game, where crafting and resource gathering is available -has to get compared to Minecraft.. It's truly sad to see the current generation of gamers and casuals..And for some reason, everyone seems to forget that roughly 65% of minecraft is community made.I know of nobody who play Minecraft Vanilla singleplayer/multiplayer anymore.. Nobody..Everyone plays on modified servers which were made by the community..Notch made the base game, we made the rest.%Review-This is only a lite-review.I will do a proper in-depth review of the game, once it has been released in it's 'final' state.Excluding updates of course. Well, perhaps a hotfix or two, after the release. (something always go wrong..)

								This game is pretty special and I'm only just scratching the surface of the tutorial.The cliche would be to write something along the lines of "if you like Minecraft, were disappointed with StarForge and play MMOs then you'll be right at home" but there's so much more to this game. I forsee this being an amazing experience online as the community grows, learns the game and gets creative.

content:

Early Access Review
								Even though it is in early access, it still has many more things in it than other builders do.  You can create vehicles to travel/battle creatures, manage colonies, setup automated defenses and attract monsters to them.  I have been playing this and EQNext.  Neither game is finished, but this game has many more features.  There are some stability issues and it has not been optimized for performance, yet.  So, if you have a low end PC, it may be wise to wait until it releases.Fast forward 2 years, and I'm still hopeful it all comes together.  The crowds are growing turgid with negativity by spewing comments about how much money they have pulled in.  People obviously do not know how much developers and designers cost.  A Jr. Dev, that will work at a much slower pace and produce bugs, starts around $60k/yr.  A Sr. Dev, that should work much quicker and more efficiently has no necessary cap on their costs, but it usually floats around the $100k/yr area.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Planet explorers, in many ways, is silmilar to Everquest Landmark.  But better.  It has a create, story, multiplayer, and adventure mode, depending on what you are looking for.  The Build system for structures is great, maybe even better the EQ.  The planet is filled with minerals and underground cave systems.  The Build system for weapons and vehicals is very good.  I am no artest, but I found it very easy to use, with a little practice, and can see how someone with more skill then me can take it and create awesome things.I paid for a Founders pack with EQ Landmark and I should of just got this game.  EQ is fun, but the MMO part of it really stinks.  The only interaction is to look at others creations, as you run by, and fight for claims and minerals.  I may edit this after Landmark offically comes out, but what I have seen for the last month or so of beta does not impress me much, and this game has everything I was looking for.The only real bugs I've encounterd are falling through the map after a crashing my car and landing upside down, and crashing twice to desktop(with a game pop-up that an error was encountered.).  I'm about 10 hours in and it looks like there is a lot more interesting story to go.  If you like minecraft, but wish there was more story, and were thinking about EQ Landmark, this is the game for you!

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								My first hour of playing the game and I'm impressed with the open world, NPC interaction and the quest system. I’m just starting on the crafting tree, once you learn to click on the scripts then you can replicate items – it’s a breeze. Easier than Minecraft in that you don’t have to select each resource, drag it to the crafting table then craft it. On the Con side the character movement controls – it’s not as immersive as minecraft. I might have missed some control configuration but I’m definitely do not like the way it’s done. I’ll keep playing around with to see if it’s a configuration.  Also chasing down NPC to talk to them and missing them and having to chasing them down again was a pain – funny – but a pain. ;) Overall I would recommend it (if the movement controls can be improved) the game has a lot of potential.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Without a doubt the best game I have played of this genre! It manages to captures the essence of frontier planatery exploration while allows for a very playable game. When they say it's a sandbox game, they mean it. You are not restricted in playstyle and can easily play the game in so many different ways. You can play it like a basic action game, running around and hunting monsters. You can play it like minecraft, building elaborate structures. You can play it almost like spore, creating interesting designs. Or you can even play it like a management game. The wealth of possibilties was something that really took me back.What is most important however, is that it is still an early access game, but it doesn't play much like one. The game feels quite robust and has less bugs and problems than in some post-released games. This does not however, mean there is no work to be done, it is not finished and can only really get better. Would definately recommend this game, absolutely amazing.

But still the best crafting system integrated into a game to date
