number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Had it for about a week now, and so far the impression is good!First off, the creation system is amazing and to be commended. Honestly it allows for nearly unparalleled design freedom, limited only by the resources available to your character, which to be honest aren't too difficult to obtain. Making vehicles and weapons that you can use in-game without having to mod them in is spectacular, and overall the system is fairly easy to use and understand.The mining is effective, if a bit on the clunky side, as the camera often jumps around or makes it hard to see what you're doing, but it ends up being more a minor annoyance than anything game breaking. If you find it unenjoyable enough you can always skip it by hunting and buying all the resources you need from NPC's with meat.Combat is fun but unfinished, the animations and hit detection aren't the best, especially with melee weapons. It can be hard to tell when you've landed a hit, as the sound effects are placeholder and creatures don't really react much to it. Guns I feel are a lot more effective and fun to use, and hunting is overall a fun part of the game. It just needs work, which apparently it will get in the alpha .8 versions.The controls for the game are all-in-all pretty good. They get the job done, they don't feel too counter-intuitive, and they aren't a big hindrance in most aspects of gameplay. The only negative for me personally when playing was I found it annoying to switch weapons, particularly if you're switching to a sword and shield, because there is no way to scroll through weapons currently you have to assign both to number keys, which means you have to equip both the sword AND shield. With guns it's less of an issue, but it would be nice to be able to scroll through weapons easier, and to be honest if you have a shield it should auto-equip the best one with a sword.The world is definitely one of the best parts of the game, with a HUGE variety in both the flora and fauna, in different parts of each biome, and different biomes. Creatures have basic behaviours, for instance herbivores will form a herd and fend off predators as a group, whereas some predators may hunt in packs. When a creature is wounded it may attempt to run away, and predators will actively hunt prey. They do not eat prey yet, which means you can get free resources if you chase a predator off a carcass, but that may be added in later as well.Each biome also offers different herbs you can collect which have different uses, adding extra incentive to explore (as if the beautiful world with interesting creatures isn't incentive enough), and the various NPC survivors you meet will fill you in on the backstory of the game, including events that happened on earth/mars, and what causes the divide between earthlings and martian settlers.The Quest system is pretty basic; go here, do this, do that, save this person, escort them, collect these resources, etc. Nothing revolutionary, but the rewards make them worth doing I guess, and the backstory is interesting.Build mode (what you use to construct buildings) is overall pretty intuitive and fun, with many different shapes to choose from and ways to place them, you are pretty much limited by your imagination. Want a Dark Tower of Doom? Build it. Want an underwater castle? Build it. Want to live on a mountain, or IN a mountain? Go ahead. The free build mode allows you to place things anywhere you want around your character, which is waaaaay better than the minecraft way of doing things, where you have to move your character everywhere to build things.Crafting is very, very complex and deep, with each component being craftable, and in turn being used to make something even bigger and more complex. You will need to craft the components and have all the resources on you if you are to import a vehicle/weapon from the creation system, which makes perfect sense to me.For an early access game, and especially an alpha, I think it's one of the most polished ones I've played. It's fun, and it has so much potential, I honestly would recommend it if you can see past the few small issues there are and you enjoy exploration, building, hunting, and driving things you design.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								A sandbox single/multiplayer tailored-story-driven or randomly generated RPG action shooter trader vehicular colony-builder farming mining creating exploring game.Basically, it's the "everygame" at long last, and unlike many Early Access games it's not only living up to its promises but far surpassing them!-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------But the reason I really love this game isn't its gameplay, it's the incredible story they're weaving with the single player, one of the greatest science fiction tales I've seen!You are one of many colonists heading to planet Maria, a seeminly perfect "garden" planet. When entering orbit a mysterious manmade looking object collides with the ship leading to you and many other colonists abandoning ship in escape craft and landing on Maria's southern continent, while the ship has crashed on the northern continent. You then spend the game rounding up survivors, unravelling the secrets of Maria, the possible secrets of the crew, the tensions between the colonists from Earth and Mars, and uncovering some INCREDIBLE vistas and revelations.*Update 29/12/15* The 0.9 build was just released and so much has been improved since I last played back at 0.8.- Movement is now fantastically fluid. A couple of animation issues on certain terrain but nothing you wouldn't expect in a sandbox game.- Melee combat is now actually fun.- MONORAILS!- MORE STORY!- Fantastic improvements to the UI. They've really been putting a lot of thought into it.- Probably a ton of other features, I'll let you know when I've played some more!

Creatures have basic behaviours, for instance herbivores will form a herd and fend off predators as a group, whereas some predators may hunt in packs. When a creature is wounded it may attempt to run away, and predators will actively hunt prey. They do not eat prey yet, which means you can get free resources if you chase a predator off a carcass, but that may be added in later as well.Each biome also offers different herbs you can collect which have different uses, adding extra incentive to explore (as if the beautiful world with interesting creatures isn't incentive enough), and the various NPC survivors you meet will fill you in on the backstory of the game, including events that happened on earth/mars, and what causes the divide between earthlings and martian settlers.The Quest system is pretty basic; go here, do this, do that, save this person, escort them, collect these resources, etc. Nothing revolutionary, but the rewards make them worth doing I guess, and the backstory is interesting.Build mode (what you use to construct buildings) is overall pretty intuitive and fun, with many different shapes to choose from and ways to place them, you are pretty much limited by your imagination. Want a Dark Tower of Doom? Build it. Want an underwater castle? Build it. Want to live on a mountain, or IN a mountain? Go ahead. The free build mode allows you to place things anywhere you want around your character, which is waaaaay better than the minecraft way of doing things, where you have to move your character everywhere to build things.Crafting is very, very complex and deep, with each component being craftable, and in turn being used to make something even bigger and more complex. You will need to craft the components and have all the resources on you if you are to import a vehicle/weapon from the creation system, which makes perfect sense to me.For an early access game, and especially an alpha, I think it's one of the most polished ones I've played. It's fun, and it has so much potential, I honestly would recommend it if you can see past the few small issues there are and you enjoy exploration, building, hunting, and driving things you design.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
Product received for free
												I have only played 15 hours and haven't even tried multiplayer, but I wanted to still say what I think of it so far.It's great! It has a plethora of issues but all in all it's really fun to play.It's like Mine Craft or Landmark with actual gameplay. Don't get me wrong, I like both of those games too, but after building my sky castle in Minecraft I just always hit a brick wall. What to do with it? Well Planet Explorers tries to answer that question. It has huge enemies that can attack your settlement. It has quests, characters, weapons, vehicles and all sorts of stuff.I should mention the negative points too though. Well... Everything that I just listed there doesn't work all that great. The game looks like a 10 years old MMO (Star Wars Galaxies comes to mind) and the animations range from ok to horrible. There are many bugs and just weird design choices, can't move while mining? Why?It's really easy to beat pretty much any enemy if you just are patient enough to run in circles and hit them in the back. They are mostly slow and not very smart.Also I recommend you just skip all the parts where the game tries to hold your hand. In the very beginning there is a tutorial that I guess would have gone through everything in excruciating detail. Thankfully there was a door with the word "EXIT" just behind me. I ran straight though it and was eternally grateful I did. The game does a good job teaching you the ropes as you go on, the tutorial was really unnecessary.So there you have it. It feels like an unfinished game that has had a very limited budget made by people who had a huge vision. They had a ton of stuff they wanted to put in and not enough resources to actually succeed.Still, somehow they managed to make a game that is definitely worth your while. And just for making a Mine Craft-like game that actually feels like a complete game rather than a fun tech demo is a feat in and of itself.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								First impression is pretty incredible. Glorious 3D environments with vibrant flora and fauna sprawling in all directions greet players first thing out of the gate, complete with a skybox full of planets and stars at night. The spirit of adventure takes center-stage, with a massive open world to explore and several modes of travel with more on the way. System to design custom swords and guns is implemented and looks versatile, but seems to require some getting used to, as with the UI for designing and erecting buildings. Running and jumping animations are somewhat clunky, and character customization is minimal for now, but these things are all minor problems surrounding what looks like a game with vast potential. Worth the price tag even during alpha release.In words closer to my typical format; it's the margarita produced if you shoved Phantasy Star Universe, Monster Hunter, and Starbound into a blender with tequila and a bunch of ice.

												If the trailer catches your eye, then download the DEMO.   I played the demo and was hooked, I played for 2 days then realized I'm in quite deep so better buy it.   After buying it I expected to re-do what I had already played but no, the old data from the demo goes to your existing game you began with! Game is really fun to play with no frustrations, as long as you stock up on the things that you've already learned. If this game is lacking stuff or has too much stuff, then welcome to the club for people who are looking for the right game for themself.   Again, download the DEMO if you don't want to have to read moronic reviews like this one.    P.S. go through the tutorial and repeat the first 20 minutes of the game if you failed to listen like me.   Cheers! Awesome game devs!

content:
Posted: January 10
												I'm coming up on 300 hours with Planet Explorers that goes back to mid-alpha.  Most of my time has been spent in Adventure mode where I can roam the open world and do what I want, when I want.  The open sandbox nature of the game melds well with my playstyle.  As a voxel based game, using the Unity 5 engine, you can change the landscape around you.  Dig down to mine for resources, tunnel out a mountain to lay a monorail or flatten the mountaintop.  Map sizes range from an 8x8km map up to a 40x40km map - which seems huge.  The land is populated by creatures that could be docile or hostile - up to you to find out which is which.  There are also NPC factions that may be friendly - or not!  :)To me, the biggest strength of the game is the creation modes.  There are two.  First is the Build mode that allows you to create buildings and bases in the open world.  Choice of blocks is a bit limited to square blocks or others based on a 45° angle.  This means you can, for instance, build a symmetrical octagon but not an equal sided hex.  Addition of 30/60° blocks would open up many more possibilities.  Also, blocks are 'fixed' in orientation.  One face of the block will always face north.  Even with these limitations, people have created some incredible things.The second mode is the Creation mode that allows you to build items from weapons and armor to vehicles that drive or fly.  Orientation of the blocks is somewhat limited here too, but you have more freedom than in the Build mode.  Using things like the mirror modes in the creator, you can build objects that are symmetrical and can then be painted and decaled to give your creation a finished look.  Creation of items can often start with a question of, "I wonder if I can create...".  Many hours can be spent finding the answer to that question.  If you look in the Steam workshop, you can see some awesome things that people have created.  For people who have spent some hours in the Creator, some of these objects can leave them shaking their heads wondering, "How in the world did they do that?"In short, if you like games like Minecraft, but with a better resolution - of the blocks, at least, give this game a try.  There is a demo, so you can try it out and see if you like it.  I like it, obviously - with the hours I have put in it and will continue to do so.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
Product received for free
												So far I'm overall enjoying this game, but it does have problems. I'm unfinished with the storyline, but other reviewers have covered that, so I won't get too into it. I may change this review after I beat the storyline. I apologize for the fact my review seems more negative than positive, but I am enjoying it more than I'm annoyed with the issues.Pros:- The building system could be refined but is overall easy to work with and building nice structures isn't particularly difficult. I also really dig the custom creation, save for the armor--I would have highly preferred there was a base we could paint over, as the creation method is far too blocky to look normal as clothes. I wanted to make some skimpy armor for my guy that matched the female version, but it sure seems impossible with the tools you're given.- Fighting is a strong point--I really like the combat system, shooting bows and guns is fun, and the difficulty is good. Hunting is enjoyable. The turrets are also nice. The swords are not as enjoyable, and I haven't used them much.- Crafting system is solid and pretty damn expansive. No complaint at all here. Very easy to use.- Resource gathering is painless.- The fast travel system is pretty well done, also, but it does make the motorbikes feel pretty useless.-  I looooove the character creation. Probably a minor detail to most people, though.- The world is gigantic and easy to get lost in. I've spent a lot of time so far just wandering and finding different areas.----Cons:- The armor creation system (mentioned above!)- Enemy animations don't line up well sometimes. I do really enjoy fighting, don't get me wrong, but it does tend to hit you when it looks like it shouldn't and not get hit when it should have. In multiplayer, the other character model is often not where it should be, even though you're playing LAN.- The AI is wonky, both for allies and enemies. It just acts really weird sometimes. I've sometimes fought baddies high up only for them to suddenly jump and kill themselves for no obvious reason, or had someone I was bringing somewhere just...run away, only for the quest to fail because they got attacked. This is somewhat unfrequent, but it happens.- The person who got this for me thought it was still in early access. I didn't know it wasn't until I came to review--it feels like it is. It's clearly a good game, and like I said I am overall enjoying it, but it doesn't feel finished. I'm nervous about the reviews that say the story mode ends abruptly. It looks like they are still developing this game, so hopefully it will still reach this stage.- The fact you have to manually close a server you're hosting with task manager is ridiculous. Not that it's hard, but it's annoying and feels very lazy.- Movement does have some issues. The random rolls and oversteps have killed or hurt me a couple times when I was too high. The ground vehicle movement is very weird, though I have yet to try the other vehicle types. (Will update when/if I do.) The camera controls are actually very easy to control, though.- No way to track other players, afaik :( It's really frustrating to open the map when someone is getting attacked and try to figure out how to get to them. I also really wish there were custom markers you could follow like you can with quests.

								Absolutely love this game - even at the lowest graphic settings the world is breathtaking.Once you get the hang of the controls they are fairly intuitive - the build function and ability to make your own custom objects and vehicles is a big plus too.The wide range of biomes and almost complete destructibility of the world increases the 'real feel' of the game, and the crafting system (replicator) is one of the best I've seen yet.Only downside possibly is that it is very graphic intensive - I have a fairly high spec mac and i have the graphics set to their lowest setting.  It is a bit buggy but I would consider a  must have  for anyone who likes a good sandbox adventure game and is looking for high customisability.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Lots of people seem to complain about this game but I have nothing but praise so far.1. Performance was substandard until I made a few changes to graphics and perfomance prefrances then it orked great (I should also add my laptop is certianly not a good laptop.)2. People were complaining about vehicles but so far I have had no problems. (Tho I've only used one.)3. People were saying that the sounds and the graphics were bad But like I said before my laptop is hardly meant for gaming and with a few minor changes to settings the game is visualy and audibly stunning and has an amazing soundtrack.4. people were coplaining about some of th quests but now that I've done a few I realise they blew those way out of preportion and the quests are actually not all that bad (So far at least) 5. people complained about the combat but contrary to what they said it I actualy found it quite smooth and most definately enjoyable. (And I haven't even gotten a single skill yet)6. I can't really say much about crafting yet exept that it takes a little while to figure out but is easy to figure out and use once you do (at least with items, I haven't built athing else yet)7. it is surprisingly realistic with a variety of health factors including desiese, malnutrition and even mental health with different medicins for different things but this systm is well done and I don't see it becoming a chore. (Tho admitedly I havn't gotten all that far)8. character customistion is amazing, so simple a child could could do it yet it is still easy to make your character look the way you want it to (Keep in min tho there are only so many options as far as that goes)9. The game feels right, it feels magical and majestic yet also dangerous at times and is the only game in a long time that has time warped my mind and stolen my day. (Only 3 games capture this spark for me and they are not surprisingly all games that had alot of effort put into their creation, the other two are Fable 2 and The last of us.If there is a downside to this game I'd say it's that you probably need alot of time on your hands to really get into it so if you are an extremely busy person then if you buy it you will probably end upputting it aside until you holidays or something. (of course if you have too much time on your hands this is an upside.)From what I have experienced so far I rate it 10/10

content:
Posted: January 2
												Time for the G.B.F. The good! The bad! And the fugly. (The full frontal review, no TL;DR here)So this holiday season, I finally got time to not-adult. You know, subsist on a steady diet of chimichangas and rum spiked egg nog... hellava combo coming back up for an encore. So like any green thing thats avoiding any and all contact with the outside world I decided to dive into indie-land and throw my hard won shiny coins at Steam, thus bringing us, to Planet Explorers. (This is an early release, so, some of the things may be fixed or unfuqed in the future, so I'm burping up salsa and crumbs on what the game is right at this moment. Like right now... at this moment... and stuff.)Okay First, the Good. And seriously folks, I thought about this stuff in the shower, it was that good. Wink wink.Graphically it is spot on great to look at. Well till someone wants to build a mega base of total badassery among the fields and flowers. But hey, progress requires alot of things to die for my needs. The colors are vibrant and stand out pulling you into the world and sharply contrasting the view so the little things stand out. Plus they fixed the blurry font so I didn't need to put on my spectacles to read and then blur the world. This game first off is a visual feast, alien critters (that must all die for my throne of meat) really look strange and for the most part unique. Except for the monkey things that throw poo and have audio like chittering monkeys... It looks and sounds like an alien world with the same ol biomes given a bit of a twist to make them stand out a bit from the norm... Best example would be the mushroom mountains in the grasslands.Character customization is in depth enough to make you look different from other people, although i'm willing to bet in multiplayer it comes down to recognizing someones hair and outfit. Speaking of outfits, BOOYAH! The late game outfits again look and feel futuristic, with glowing lights, weird angles and questionable monotone with flavor color overlay schemes... but still far future.People are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥+ Don't get attached. It's good to see a game with political undertones, because as a green ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, I know humans are great at snubbing one another. Right off the bat (Drumroll) Martians and Earthlings (Ba-Dum-Tiss) don't like one another. See even in the future, humans gotta human. In the Story-mode of the game this plays out fairly well and has a good thread to keep RPGers asking questions, and if the option were available, sides would be picked. And some NPCs (Hailey! My blue haired Martian anime sweetheart!) die. Of course if your totally prepared a *few* can be prevented... But that was an alien invasion to fort Badass II that was not prepared for 250 laser turrets, a fully trained combat squad with top end everything... and me, sipping spiced cider watching a futile invasion. (Although some deaths are purely scripted and try as I may with overwhelming destruction, some deaths can't be prevented.)Now for the bad... The audio, omg the audio! 95% of the time it was immersive and really reeled me in. But there are moments... Looking at you monkey things. That rip you right out of it, or sent me into fits of throwing my headset across the room. The main music track is glorious... till it hits the high notes that make a beagle howl in pain. Some of the settlement items drown out spoken dialogue with their droning and some you wonder if they even work from being too quiet. Turrets will literally make you crap your pants! (I had to wear pull-ups about 20 hours in.) Especially the gatling turrets. Most people are willing to unzip and let a warm stream of truth leave a messy if slightly briney coating all over the spoken dialogue, myself, not really... It's bad... almost on unprofessional levels. You can read along the words in the text box don't match up, some people are faking accents, Some have residual background noise, or were recorded too quietly and had to have the volume cranked up post production, or just failed with getting and using a popper. Still I have heard and cringed at vastly worse... So I'll give Pathea a pass for just trying to coordinate audio, rather than using a central recording studio.(It's tough man.)Usefully useless NPCs. A major facet is colony / resource management. Thus you get people to lord over, and hooboy, do I like commanding weak humans into a pure force of fire wielding death monkeys! And some of them right out of the gate come skilled for such an endeavor. And others make for an exellent fall back crew to be trained up to fill roles highly needed by the legion of "don't you even think of invading alien scum!". The biggest detractor is in storyline mode whereas it's nearly non-existant in adventure mode. You get a guy like Chen who makes for a great first string soldier to train your defense force, but due to quests he's too busy (aka the scripting wont allow it.) Forcing you to train at least one duplicate (who hopefully does not die) to play both primary task and trainer. This happens quite a bit, and super late into the story mode you will have acess to some very skilled individuals who are sorely needed for maximum effect for the colony as a whole, but are nothing more than window dressing after becoming part of your team. Yeah Tank, F-you too buddy... Nice skill set you have there... The farmers could use you man, oh you can't be assigned... And I can't just up and shoot you in the face... crud. (But I'll totally give a pat on the back for adding the Korean girl-child. Having a young person of mid-teen years added immersion to the fact it was a COLONY SHIP and not everyone would be old farts, quite immersive.)Questing is not really rewarding... kinda. Okay again the RPG elements are spot on, I can't dish on that... not even force a slippery wet fart in the general direction of story questing, both Story and adventure modes do a fairly good job of rewarding the player in that aspect. Do mission = unlock more of the adventure to be told with some sugar sprinkles on top... the pretty colored sprinkles like on cup-cakes. But the side missions is where I can definately squidge out a wet fart with the power to break my thunder buckets gravitational pull. Whats the point? Okay in some cases, you may unlock a follower who will be your high maintainence combat buddy... That's cool. But for the most part, the basic filler fetch quests Do X, Craft X, Gift X, yield nothing... Like that chocolate factory guy (NAME COPYRIGHTED) The same one who angrilly exclaims you get nothing. Side missions are a filler for now that mostly give nothing in return. Grumpy Goblin.And to the Fugly... the things that make your toes curl up in terror like waking up next to you best friends dog naked.(Don't ask.)FIRST Whisky Tango Foxtrot Pathea? Adding theme music to Chen?!? (Latest update) Look if it was an April fools update, I would totally understand. But it drowns out dialogue during story missions. Actually drowns out everything. It is so loud and breaks the living hell out of the fun factor I got to the point of trying to lock him in a box filled with live grenades. Pull it out, pull it out now! This is one baby (the theme song) that needs smothered in the crib!The unskippable repeating wonder credits. Okay kudos on the ending and where it leaves us salivating for more... mmm freshly smothered baby meat... Fact is once you hit the credits your new old friend will be Ctrl + Alt + Del. Theres no other way to stop it, and it's on a loop... it just keeps going on and on, like this review.Random gen NPC mutants from planet X. Random generator needs tweeking so everyone doesn't look inbred. Nuff said.Seriously though, Despite my belching. This game is filled to the brim so far with many "oooo neet!" moments, excellent crafting, a intriguing story overall, and reminders that you always need to be prepared. So in closing, Like Survival / Exploration / RPG? Definately Get this game!

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Planet Explorers is a great game with amazing potential - much of which has already been realised in spite of the game only being in Alpha, with the ability to create all sorts of gizmos from cars, boats, planes, helicopters, buildings and even the kitchen sink - literally. You really are only confined by the limits of your own imagination.Having been playing the single player mode since Alpha 0.81, there are issues in multiplayer that really need addressing (A0.831 being the latest version at the time of writing). Also given that this is still in Alpha I cannot stress that these are issues that will eventually be resolved in due course.Undoubtedly the biggest issue thus far has been that hosted servers do not always save your progress. You can spend hours upon hours creating things (which luckily you can save as isos to use again at a later date), but if you're unfortunate enough not to be able to do this and your server fails to either save or to appear on the server list, then all your hard work will have been for nought.The game also has a tendency to spawn your character underneath blocks you've already placed, which is no better demonstrated than logging into the game and finding your character face-deep in the dirt under your house. This latter point is obviously an issue regarding optimisation that can easily be resolved, though servers not saving your hard work is a much more serious issue.While single player 'story mode' and multiplayer 'build mode' seem quite stable, multiplayer 'adventure mode' on the other hand seems very buggy by comparison.In spite of all this however, I'm very happy to say that the potential of this game is such that it warrants further and continued interest on my part*, though I may update this review as and when necessary. 4.5/5--------* The game has been so promising that I bought extra copies for my friends.

								I don't normally do reviews for games or anything else for that matter but after having played this game for over 400 hours as of posting this I have to say this game is becoming one of my favorites and it isn't even finished yet. content:
Posted: April 10
												Planet explorers is a mix of GTA and Terraria, with added features that makes it quite compelling. For example, it has an awesome basebuilding/colony feature and you can design your own vehicles/weapons/armor. The beginning is a littebit unwieldy, but you are rewarded with a huge range of things to do, if you get the hang of it. Youtube tutorials are your friend on this one. The ability to create your own vehicles/weapons/armor is quite unique and the workshop is brimming with creations that you can use. Special praise: You can build a monorail! Although, that is more of a Shelbyville feature.The music and story of the campaign are solid. The multiplayer mode has not been tested, but IF bug-free, it could be awesome.In a nutshell: I like this game enough to write a review, although I disdain writing reviews. I am not sorry that this review reads like the research article I should have written instead.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS REVIEW:When I first saw the trailer and images on the store page for "Planet Explorers" I thought to myself wow this game has lots of potential, and it looks like lots of fun to play, but to my dismay this is what I got:The game starts out with poor dialogue, its text based, the letters are tiny and the npcs feel dead (Villages feel dull/dead too), the npcs don't really move around or do much, they just sit there, vendors are pretty much useless they only sell stuff that are easy to come by, the only benefit of npcs is the ability to recruit, that being said you gotta get them a full set of gear, because they come into the world like you with completely garbage items.In short term let me make Pros & Cons,--Pros-----Good Concept & IdeaFun DiggingYou can climb any mountain by hugging the wallCreation ModeCons-------Friendly Npc's are completey useless & redundentVillages feel extremely dull and deadEnemy Npcs are too strong (Even at starting level, some enemies can even 1 shot you)Obtaining easy weapons/gear is quite frustratingThe Fatigue system is completely stupid, [when fatigued your rendered useless in every shape way or form]Weapons do to little of damage for enemies your levelMultiplayer Digging/Mining Glitches (Cant see other player tunnel)Swimming controls are awfulMelee Combat aiming is awfulLighting Glitches while in Mines/Digged holesThe time it takes to get places on footGeneral Glitches (Falling through world/underground)Interface is quite awful, the weapons 1-10 bar doesn't work properlyThe Character creation is not that great, & is nowhere near completeMultiplayer Search System is terribleetc........Overall this game is definatly not worth its Early Access price of $20, I bought it for $15 on sale, and its not even worth that. I would say at its current stage the game is worth no more than $5, because they still have alot to prove and bring to the table.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								EDIT/UPDATE: Something new that really chafes me that I *HAD* to add to my review!  I've tried to wrap my head around it, and even though in some ways I can see the pros, ultimately I have to feel as though it's in direct violation of the Early Access Program rules of Steam.  Now, I'm not trying to go out of my way to make trouble for the developers of this game... I truly think it has tons of potential, tons of possibility to do well, and I just wish they'd get their heads out of the butts and iron out the core features like CONTROL INPUTS for the CORE FUNCTIONALITY OF THE GAME (and before anybody says that controller-support isn't a core function... it's LISTED in their INPUT section under the CONTROL menu, with some Joystick buttons even listed as defaults, while only half of an entire gamepad/joystick works, but also interferes with Xpadder/Pinnacle working properly -- there are quite a few people that have medical issues, myself included if you count aches/pains from old age, that can only comfotably game with a controller... most times I even use a controller to navigate through the OS and such... Unity HAS built-in controller support, so either iron it out, or turn it off so people can use XPadder or Pinnacle!!!  Buyers have been asking/begging for it for OVER A YEAR NOW!).  Anywho, here's what's chafing me... Steam's Early Access is about ANYBODY that pays for early access, gets to experience the game as it goes.  Planet Explorer's decided to make an Alpha-Beta team I guess.  And no, I'm not "butt-hurt that I couldn't be on the team"... as far as I know you just have to opt into it, and anybody in EA can do that as far as I'm aware.  It just blows my mind though, that first you have to pay for EA, expecting to get all patches and updates as they happen, and then a SUB-GROUP is made within that EA for "BETA-TESTING" of an ALPHA!?  WTH!?  Every EA I've played to date, I haven't had to babysit "how I get my patches and when"... when updates are made, you just get them auto-patched via steam.  Now, GRANTED... one of those pros... having a beta-team makes sure it's nothing that will outright break and destroy the game when a patch is pushed, but that's what internal Q/A is supposed to be for; (Or even... I dunno, early-access!?).  So now, of all people that pay for EA, hypothetically 50% that are in beta get the latest "beta updates" as they happen, while those that didn't know or couldn't be bothered to opt into beta, have to WAIT until the devs decide the "alpha patch" is up to "alpha standards!?" before they release it.  Perfect example... I haven't opted into the beta-testing, but I launch my PE game right now, and my currently running and available public version is 0.871... yet, on the steam page for PE, I even quote, the most recent patch is "A0.886 Beta Build Released on Steam" (this isn't flipping WoW with their PTR for crying out loud... this game isn't even in full freaking release yet!!!).  See what I mean!?  When has there ever been a BETA within an ALPHA/Early-Access!?  How long does time have to go on before we have so many silly sub-levels to early-access/beta-testing before it's just too absurd to make anymore sense of!?  "Oh yeah, I'm an alpha-access beta-tester to the early-access beta-alpha which is in place to iron out all updates before they hit the closed-alpha-beta-alpha to ensure that everything is ironed out when the game goes beta-alpha-beta in a couple more months"... WTF!?Well, game seems decent, interesting, fun and procedurely-generated.  Lots of potential in this title.Biggest downside though is, been sitting on this title as it collects dust because of all the so-called "upcoming improvements and fixes".  Controller-support in this game is horribly broken, so much so that you can't even use Xpadder/Pinnacle to map out a custom-config... since the game semi-initiliazes control of the controller/joystick with no options to turn it off on the game-side of things.  Wouldn't be so big an issue, except for people like myself where playing constantly with a mouse and having to sit forward all the time start to kill my back and wrist after awhile.Wouldn't fault the game so much for having broken controller-support... but be nice if devs either got controller-support accurate, or just left it alone so people could again jury-rig their own support via Xpadder/Pinnacle... as it stands it's a giant speed-bump/road-block.Other than that, everything else about the game seems to run somewhat decently and looks really fun... just a shame that those that might require sitting back with a gamepad can't exactly dive right in... been really longing to play this game more.  And for that reason, I can't exactly recommend it... as others might find themselves in the same predicament as myself.  Not everybody has tons of money, and in this day and age several live on a tight budget... with so many broken/problematic games, people want to feel comfortable and confident that they can make a leap of faith in buying what looks and seems to be a half-decent game.  Problem is, gaming controls/functionality are a core-element that by now designers and developers should have figured out... it's not rocket-science, it's not like anybody's reinventing the wheel.  So for the sake that nobody drops the clams on this to find out, as I did, that they're simply unable to play it the way they want to and for a decent amount of time in one sitting, I can't exactly outright recommend this, at least, not without putting a huge WARNING out there.WARNING: If you're able to play for long hours with a keyboard/mouse this game may be okay for you... if you typically need to jury-rig up another input-interface/controller-setup either in a game or jury-rigged outside the game... WAIT and SAVE YOUR MONEY until they confirm there's some sort of fix or update to this. -_-

number of helpful: 19 of 37 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've only tried the Story Mode so far, and after that, I don't know if I'll be up for trying the other modes.The game has potential but it's still very early to determine what the end result will be. Playing, it feels like the developers are still unclear on what they want to do with some features. From what I've played, quests have been simply going from point A to a very far point B then back, or gather X amount of resources A, B and C, or a combination of the two. They are long, tedious and do little to keep you wanting to play more.The crafting system is decent, but very early on, you'll get very complicated scripts that require you to create many different materials from many different resources in order to create a single Item. It wouldn't be so bad, if resource gathering was fast and entertaining, which it's not. early tools take ages to gather resources, and you're stuck with them until you figure you have to buy more scripts from an NPC.The combat system is barely worth speaking about. If you don't notice the little enemy health bar that appears in the upper left corner of the screen, you won't even know if you're landing any strikes or not, until either you or your enemy are down.You can put items for use in the 1-9 bar, a la Minecraft, and it works well, but the only way to know which Item you have equipped is by looking at the square left of button 1, which shows what you're currently using. I guess that's ok, but it'd be less confusing if it just highlighted the Item you've selected. Another problem is that if you're using a sword and Shield and you change to a pickaxe to do some mining, when you switch  back to the sword, the shield will stay unequipped, forcing you to go and equip it again, which can be annoying considering how you can be attacked at any time.One other problem I had is that throughout the time I spent playing, I felt like I was doing something (or rather everything) wrong. Following the questline brought me to face enemies against whom I had no chance. I constantly wondered if there was something I missed, something that should have prepared me for the challenge, but there seemed to be nothing there.Overall, the game has potential, but I cannot recommend it to anyone, simply because it's too unfinished. I wish I had waited a year or two more to play it in a much more polished state. I know I'll have to wait at least that long to come back to it.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								unfortunately due to its current state and price I cannot honestly recommend this. The storyline although there, isnt finnished. So only about a third of the map is explorable. Adventure mode offers little challenge. You are just given the plans to make ever item in the game, when you start. And if you dont want to make them there is an always available shop menu.Farming isnt worth doing as you buy a seed, plant it, wait, harvest and then just get 2 of the crop. Then you have to buy another seed. As the crop item can usualy be bought at half the price of the seed. You may as well buy that and not wait.Colony building consists of building 5 to 7 items and placing them, then getting a few people to "live" there. You then supply them with food, water, armour, weapons, assign them a job working the farm. Then thay stand around doing nothing all day.With All that said, this is one of the most promising games I have seen all year. Graphics are almost perfect for the game. Mining is even challenging. Combat is fun although needs tuning a little. Stability is almost perfect with one crash in 24 hours gameplay. Making your own designs of vehicles works fantastic. Using the rocket pack to gain height, then switching to hanglider and gliding around is almost a game in itself.And yes I understand this is an Early access game, but one of the keywords is Game, and currently there isnt enough game to play, and make this worth buying at this price. This is at present an alpha demo and should probabily be free. If you want to support the creators then buy it. Otherwise wait, and keep a close eye on it. If Its finnished, it will be good.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've been following this game for a couple years now, and it continues to get better and better. It takes a bit of time to warm up to it, but if you give it a chance, you'll find it a deeply satisfying blend of RPG, sandbox, base building, exploration, crafting, and open world survival. The AI NPC's are a fantastic addition, as well as the built-in object editor, where you can download patterns other people have created from within the game. You get to create your own avatar and customize gender, hair, eyes, skin, face, and clothing. That's a HUGE plus in my book.If you're looking for an alternative to Minecraft with better character and creature models, better environmental graphics, more streamlined crafting and building, vehicles, NPC followers, objectives, quests, and more diverse and interesting types of weapons, this is it. Truly an amazing game, even this early in development. I can't wait to see where it goes next.My friends and I have already had quite a bit of fun with this in multiplayer, although at this stage the features could use a bit of work. It would be nice to have a more fleshed out multiplayer story mode. But even as it stands, it's a ton of fun.Devs, if you read this, your idea of enhanced NPC interactions like marriage and procreation? Yes yes! Do it! Also, it appears difficult if not impossible to get NPC followers to heal themselves. Please fix that! Thank you for making such an excellent game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								First off: This game is very alpha. There's a reason it's early access. It's improving, but don't expect a complete, polished game.On the surface this just looks like yet another ripoff of Minecraft, although in this case with gorgeous graphics. It's not. It takes a whole different angle on building things, giving the player a lot of freedom to shape things exactly how they want—if they're willing to take the time to learn the still-rather-clunky UI. You can build a nice house, but you can also build your own sword, gun, vehicle and various other things. It takes the concept of crafting beyond a preset list of things and almost brings CAD into a game. Extremely unique, and while I can't promise everyone will like it, if anything in my review sounded interesting, it might be worth a try.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								On the surface Planet Explorers seems like a quick cash-in on the Crafting/Exploration genre, which is not to imply it doesn't succeed at what it intends to do. While still in Early Access this title performs very well on both fronts, and should not be dismissed for the bugs/flaws currently in-game.  The attempt at exploration Planet Explorers makes is impressive, and although the graphics may be a little dated, the scenery can be downright beautiful at times.  Even with a map as vast as the one in Planet Explorers moving forward is not always the best option, with vast cave networks easily discovered using you Handheld PC, you won't have to venture far to discover the unknown.  One flaw that currently is plaguing this title is the draw distance, and the rate at which the landscape appears, while easily written off as an Early Access issue, it is one that will need to be addressed before official release.Crafting in Planet Explorers can feel like the usual fanfare, resource tiers(wood, rock, copper, iron, etc), but the Creations Editor is where the crafting in this title moves beyond what I've encountered so far in my gaming experience. Yes, other games have had content creation, map editors, etc, but Planet Explorers brings it right to the forefront of its systems.  While the Creations Editor(a more accurate name would be Blueprint Editor) can seem daunting and unwieldy, spending time learning it's nuances will quickly show you just how robust this tool can be.  I have had a blast buidling new vehicles and testing them in Build Mode to see how well they perform, and the experience brings me back to my childhood playing with legos.While Planet Explorers is on the right path towards what, in my eyes, is the next evolution of the Crafting/Exploration genre, it is not without it's bugs. I previously mentioned the draw distance, which is an issue for immersion, but also for traversing the map in aircrafts, or other very fast moving vehicles. While travelling around the map you will have trees, animals, mountains, and more appear in front of you, often leading to emergency meneuvers.  With the robust Creation Editor, and Steam Workshop support this title has the potential to develop a large following, and create many memorable moments.  Other bugs do occur, and not all game elements are currently implemented, but I feel with our support this could be a title to throw up on the board with Minecraft, and if all the kinks are worked out it will surpass it in what it does.

												1.0.7.1 ReviewPlayed through all of story mode.  Enjoyable, but ends on a massive cliffhangerCombat:  You can't just slug it out with critters.  Dodge and kite and you'll be fine.  Also watch the skies in the grassland areas, the flying predators will try to snack on you.Colony Building:  Absolutely love this part of the game.  I'm a bit of a base building fanatic and setting up a self sustaining colony is right up my alley.Creation System for designing your own....  well almost everything.  You can design weapons and vehicles from scratch here.  The interface isn't very intuitive and I can't make stuff look good at all, but lots of people upload the specs of some pretty incredible creations.     Wouldn't mind seeing some Dev-made already ingame premades for the vehicles though.       1-2 of each basic type would do (motorbike, landrover, vertical-take-off-landing craft, boats, etc.)Negative Points:  The game still feels like it's in beta.  It's enjoyable, but feels like it lacks the polish needed to be great.  I think the vehicle controls are pretty crappy too.Still recommended, but beware it may feel unpolished.

Posted: February 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Edit: 1 year later: The tutorial is a pain, they've updated a bunch  of the graphics, sounds, etc. The theme song has words now (I liked it when it didn't :( ). I get a car really soon so I don't have to walk 500 miles earlly in the game. Yay! It stutters a lot now, but that might just be because of all the stuff I have running in the background. Apparently the story's grown since I last played, so I'll try to see what's new.Has a few bugs, but still an amazing game. It *is* still early access, but generally you won't know.8.5/10I bought this last year (I think), and the interface was a bit iffy. Collecting parts was near impossible and I thought I was just doing it wrong. The new version's UI works just as I'd expect it to (phew, I'm not crazy!). The game is one off the newfandangled voxel based games that are popping up everywhere. You mine, dig, shoot, stab and  cut (animals, plants and the ground) to get materials and use them to make inventory items like guns, healing potions, etc. All the dirt that you mined up? Well, it seems you can use that to build structures a la minecraft. There is also customization of things you build, so you can pretty much build whatever you want. I haven't really played with that yet, the screen scared me since it's too powerful, but I hear it's pretty cool.There is a main mission that you should really play to get the hang of things, and the devs seem to put out frequent updates.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I guess now would be a good time to write a review though I have never done one before.Planet Explorers I feel reminds me most of an old mmo called Star Wars Galaxies. This game combines house building, vehicle building, armor crafting, weapon crafting, and technology. As well as the normal monster huting and looting, though it is unlike you will find a weapon on a random creature.This game does have its bugs as is seen when a creature some how manages to float up a tree without moving, but hey... its alpha. The combat is fun though a bit repeatitive on the actions, same swinging animation. But to be honest the game is very fun, and a different trend then the MMO that we are used to. The graphics may fall short but this does not mean that the sceen is any less beautiful. The landscape is vast and its quite daunting to consider how long it will take to explore all of it... and thats just for the main story line.Now I believe something I should touch base on is the crafting system. As I mentioned very indepth but a bit hard to understand first off. Items you need to make you first must get the recipe from mobs or NPC's. After that you then have to find the resources and craft the specific item which is normal enough. But when you look to create a vehicle you must make sure to have the specific items your going to use when crafting it in your editor.The mining, herb picking, and diging is all very fluent and easy to get the hang of. I would highly recommend this game if you are looking for something to keep you interested while waiting for the next big mmo. I personally have not tried the multiplayer yet, but from what I understand it does work... and to be honest whats better then exploring a massive span of land with some friends.I look forward to the future updates this game offers, and I hope many of you enjoy this game as much as I do.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								With 20hrs under the belt I can safely say that this game is fantastic.  There is so much to do and so much life to the game.  I will break it down by features.Graphics:The graphics are great.  There isn't as much control over what features pertaining to graphics are used but enough to make sure your system can run it properly.  At full quality it looks stunning.  Light permeating through tree leaves, a nice not-over-done bloom effect, AA, it all works great and runs smooth.  Very pleasing to the eyes.  The voxel engine handles very well and even with an older video card, the game handles it all very well and even displays very far into the distance (im using a nvidia 560ti).    The weather is handled very nice and looks good.  Night time is actual night time.  You can hardly see at pitch black and need a torch or light.  Characters:It is great that they allow you to create your own custom character like sims or elderscrolls games.  The NPCs are active but not to the extent of say skyrim where they have jobs.  They sort of just stand around and walk here and there. You can talk to them and get a lot of story background which is great.  You can even enlist some of them to fight beside you and you can equip them with armor and weapons and whatnot.  The mercenaries have their own set of special skills too.  Some are great with swords and others with guns and so on.  Adds nicely to who you choose to follow you.  I like that the mercenaries reappear beside you when you get too far from them.Story:Great story line.  Makes you want to learn more and more about what is going on.  This coming from a guy that usually is not interested in story.  I found myself wanting to know what happened.  That doesn't happen often at all.  Sound/music: The sound was good.  The music adjusted appropriately depending on where you were and whether or not you were in the area of a hostile enemy. It was a little glitchy but I've read they are fixing that.  Sound effects fit weapons and whatnot.  It could use more attention to vehicles and sounds but overall still good.Quests:The quests are your run of the mill quests.  They are good and add to the the story.  They don't always feel quite at all like a grind.  Some can be, but that is normal it seems.  Other quests are more detailed.  I will say there are some bad bugs with some of the quests that require a npc to follow you.  That npc is prone to get stuck at a tree or rock and unlike the mercs that you hire, the quest npcs don't reappear at your side if you move too far away.  I have found that if you have a quest npc with you, if you bring out a vehicle and get in it, the npc will rellocate to your vehicle which is an unintended fix.  This leads to problems early game especially when you are travelling long distances.  When you have quest npcs with you, you can't fast travel.  If they get unexpectedly stuck in a tree you have to travel all the way back to retreive them.  This can be frustrating. There are some quests that you receive early in the game that won't be completed until later.  Many have had problems with this.  I imagine it will be fixed in later versions given this game is only early access.  SOme quests are a little buggy but that is mostly due to the fact that npcs end up getting stuck in random places.  There was one quest involving two npcs and I couldn't complete the quest because one of the npcs randomly got stuck in a mountain side and I couldn't get him down until I dug out the mountain side.Building:The game contains a lot of building which is great.  Kind of like minecraft.  You can make your own weapons and vehicles and whatnot.  You require schematics to build things and sometimes require to build one thing in order to build another.  It doesn't get overly complicated though.  The difficulty of the build is often representative of the usefulness of what you are building.  For instance, you can't just easily build a helicopter.  It requires you build a cockpick, rotors, engines, energy cells, etc.  It is a very intuitive building system that takes a little time to get use to but once you are it is very easy to use.  There is a lot of fun to be had.  A lot of creativity that can be used.  I will say the game could do better at helping you understand the proper needs of a vehicle.  I made a dune-buggy type car and I had all the pieces but in game I got this red text at the bottom that told me the car is overpowered or something.  It never really told me why it was overpowered or how to fix it.  The car still worked fine as it was.  Enemies: There are a lot of animals and enemies in the game.  Many of the animals are docile until you attack them which is nice.  Some of the animals are hostile from the start and it is fun and interesting to see which animals will attack on site and which animals will run right beside you.  The enemies are dangerous too.  Some prefer to sit back and snipe you.  Others will come slinging swords and whatnot.  Some will even mount turrets and will sling rockets and bullets at your face.  The animals and enemies come in all shapes and sizes and the size of the mob usually indicates how dangerous they are.  There are a few points where you fight some extremely large enemies and they can prove quite hard to defeat.  I will say the ranged mobs seem a lot more easy to conquer given they can be dodged easily.  Overall: Wonderful game with a ton of potential.  It already has a great deal built into and most of what will probably come from later versions is just more content.  I hope they fix some of the not-so-obvious bugs mentioned above (I am sure they will).  Creating your own camp and playing tower defense was really fun.  Being able to craft cars and helicopters and then drive them around was extremely fun.  The game does a great job easing you into the features and concepts of the game.  Very fun and leaves you wanting more (it is in alpha so that is to be expected).  I look forward to future updates and highly recommend you buying this game now if you enjoy rpg and open world sandbox games like terraria and minecraft.  There is a lot of replayability built into the game and right now about 20hrs worth of straight story line with some random quests thrown in.  It is a very balanced game.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note: Summary at the bottom of the review.Your colony ship just hit something in orbit, just as you arrived at your destination. Your lifeboat pod has crashed down, and the only other human occupant is injured and need medical attention. You have no weapons, barely any food, and your only tool is a simple knife. Welcome to Planet Explorers.Luckily, the above is not a huge problem, because this game lets you craft all of the above, and not just craft it, you can actually build your own guns and transport, chosing exactly how they should look by adding base parts (a gun has to have at least one muzzle and a grip) and then building the shape of your gun piece by piece from there. This is an Alpha game, and like all games still in early access, that means that things are not optimized. You will experience lag. You will find bugs (both the kind that tries to eat you, and the kind that just annoys you). And the grass...is awful. I recommend turning it off. Look beyond that though, and you find an exellent sandbox game that gives you a lot of freedom as to how you play and what you do. It is, even in its current "rough" state, a better game than many similar games that are considered a finished product. In short, it is a FUN game, that hopefully has a bright future!Pro:*A huge sandbox game with deformable terrain.*A very good (if a bit complex) crafting system.*An interesting setting.Con (these may be fixed before launch):*The grass is simply awful, but can be turned off.*Lag is not uncommon, especially if you've built a lot.*Still needs polish and optimization.Summary:If you are in the market for a 3D survival Sci-Fi Sandbox game, this is a solid choice that shows a lot of promise, even in its current unfinished state. If the developers sticks to it, this could easily become THE survival sandbox game to play. Even "as is" there is a lot to explore and do, and you'll likely have fun doing it! 6/10 -Recommended.For more recomendations and reviews: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/strandedkerbonaut#curation

Early Access Review
								(Early Access Review) Already a really fun game, and will be even better upon release. Very similar UI/ feel of an old MMO like "asherons call" but huge, singleplayer (multi fully does exist, I have not tried), with mining, crafting, hunting, and a great building system for vehicles and equipment. It even has a colony building and management system! Visually not bad at all, not amazing, but it is always improving and sometimes when the light catches trees or a vista correctly I still catch myself amazed by the world and its beauty. All of this is the foundation on a fun and interesting world, with decent missions and NPC writing, and a very imaginative and diverse ecosystem of wacky alien flora and fauna.

												I have been waiting a while to get this game because for a while it was getting many bad reviews. So when it was on sale for 14$ I jumped on the chance to get it. And I haven't been let down. For a matter of fact I haven't been able to play anything else. This game adds many qualities I enjoy from other games into one; Open world,RTS,FPS to name a few I won't lie and say there aren't a few glitchy things but as a early access it is playable. The colony building and the building in general took a bit to get used to but once I did it became crazy fun. Currently playing Story mode and the story, believe it or not, is really engaging. Totally thought it was going to go one way and was taken a different direction. I find myself doing quests more or less just to see what happens next. The crafting system also took a second to get used to. I am used to minecraft and ark type crafting. All in all I say if you enjoy space/futuristic,crafting,building games give this one a chance I don't think you will be disappointed either. Oh and as for the graphics I use a crappy lap top from wal mart on low graphics and it runs fine and the quality isnt bad on fast settings.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is a true open world with multiple different things to do sequentially or at the same time. I have over 100 hours logged and have enjoyed them all for the most part. It is an amazing game for building stuff. You can use the built in blocks and shapes to build amazing structures, or you can custom build all sorts of other things using the innovated custom create feature. After you have designed your whatever, you can spawn it into the world and drive it around or place it. For a game of this high level, 2-4 years development is normal. Big box games take just as long with the only difference being the betas are usually closed. Would get gored by angry bear-hippos again!

Posted: February 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Currently there are game breaking bugs and you need a pretty beastly machine to even run the game at medium settings.As of now I've played Planet Explorers since it was made available to play off and on. This is my review as of version a0.87.Earlier more stable versions allowed me to play with no problems while runing into rare bugs in story mode. I was also able to play with friends in multiplayer mode with little issues though lack of content made it boring at the time.This latest version seems to have implemented game-breaking story mod bugs as well as many performance decreasing issues that have been left unattended to. It seems Pathea takes a long time to release patches and fix issues. But the patches of content they release are amazing compared to other games, however spread very far apart making the patches not so great.I am currently NOT going to recommend the game at this time as Multiplayer can end up boring and Story Mode (Single Player) seems to have a fair share of issues and game-breaking bugs.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Alright, so, I like a lot about this game. building is fun, the world is decently interesting, I had few bugs, and only one of them prevented me from ever completing the main story. (npcs I need to complete one quest involving a certain queen of certain crab monsters won't spawn, even after starting an all new game and playing through a second time)But here lie the problems: -that's the only place TO have fun. either you play an easily bugged, massive open world adventure mode where you get to experience everything or you play the survival mode.-survival mode spawns you in a rather small piece of land with only one biome. In the center of the map is a town, revealing that you are a SECOND generation colonist, taking away all sense of "roughing it." All you can do is walk out into the wasteland and get a little iron or copper, but never enough to really build anything good or give a sense of progression. You'll probably end up making a stone hut 10 meters from the town, cowering from enemies you lack the resources to face. this is especially disheartening because it shows that the only way to get to the fun colonies and giant robots part of the game is to play the hours-long adventure mode.-there's a creative mode, but you get the same little patch of land with nothing to do but build with no challenge. pretty standard.-although building is cool, creatures can just knock it down, which means building a home is pretty pointless, because it won't protect you from anything anyway. (unless you want to build a mess of turrets that run out of bullets)-a large portion of the main quest involves walking in straight lines for miles at a time, sometimes just to look at something, then fast travel back. (which costs money)-followers constantly get stuck.-the game has little cutscenes where the camera will pan in to show you something of interest, but these scenes are unnecessarily long.a few days of my life I'll never get back... out of ten.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12
												I wish there was a "neutral" option but there isn't so I will attempt to remember to update my review If/When new updates come out that change the game.Overall Problems:      * The game plays like it was Very rushed with very little planning or attention to detail.  It has a very complex building system but no explanation as to how to use it, this could be tolerated in an Alpha game, but this should have been fixed before the game left Beta.      * The dialogue by followers is very cheesy and not vey well thought out as is most of the dialogue in the story.      * Folowers don't obey the settings like passive, stay ect. They also can't help you do anything but attack stuff and cut down trees. they do not mine resources or even collect water.      * There are no real directions or explanation of anything in game, you have to fumble through figuring out how building in every mode works and map settings if you are playing adventure mode.        * No tools to collect resources fast, everything is collected by hand, the colony "processor" will collect resources but much slower than you can collect with the lowest level tools.       * Everytime night comes around you get tons of notices that your colonists are too tired to work.        * Your colony Weapons can destroy your own base parts and your own vehicles.       * Colonists don't make their own food, you have to make the food and put it in the storage.       * You have to have all the resources for building in your personal inventory even if you are building with the colony replicator.        * There are still alot of Alpha level bugs.Story mode:      The story is okay, nothing that I would reinstall the game to play again. The conversation text is full of typo's and outright wrong words in places, and the story just ends.Adventure mode:     Adventure mode has several settings, but there is nothing explaining map setup, or tool level progression if you choose that option.  There are also not enough options in world genereation.    If you start with all items scripts already learned and there is no need to interact wil NPC's at all, if you choose to start without all the scrips already learned and you have to do alot of quests to learn to build what you need to start a colony.   Resources in this mode seem to be very deep in the gound with no settings that let you bring them closer to the surface that I was able to find.Multiplayer:        I Played on several servers, the major problem I found was that other players can simply enter build mode and take any materials you place, on one server players just picked up and took all my colony buildings without being part of my colony. ---------------------------------------------------------------------I will recommend this game if you can find the game on sale for $12 usb or less, don't get me wrong, it's an okay game once you figure out how to do everything but I don't think it's worth the $25 usd price they are asking for it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								With 20hrs under the belt I can safely say that this game is fantastic.  There is so much to do and so much life to the game.  I will break it down by features.Graphics:The graphics are great.  There isn't as much control over what features pertaining to graphics are used but enough to make sure your system can run it properly.  At full quality it looks stunning.  Light permeating through tree leaves, a nice not-over-done bloom effect, AA, it all works great and runs smooth.  Very pleasing to the eyes.  The voxel engine handles very well and even with an older video card, the game handles it all very well and even displays very far into the distance (im using a nvidia 560ti).    The weather is handled very nice and looks good.  Night time is actual night time.  You can hardly see at pitch black and need a torch or light.  Characters:It is great that they allow you to create your own custom character like sims or elderscrolls games.  The NPCs are active but not to the extent of say skyrim where they have jobs.  They sort of just stand around and walk here and there. You can talk to them and get a lot of story background which is great.  You can even enlist some of them to fight beside you and you can equip them with armor and weapons and whatnot.  The mercenaries have their own set of special skills too.  Some are great with swords and others with guns and so on.  Adds nicely to who you choose to follow you.  I like that the mercenaries reappear beside you when you get too far from them.Story:Great story line.  Makes you want to learn more and more about what is going on.  This coming from a guy that usually is not interested in story.  I found myself wanting to know what happened.  That doesn't happen often at all.  Sound/music: The sound was good.  The music adjusted appropriately depending on where you were and whether or not you were in the area of a hostile enemy. It was a little glitchy but I've read they are fixing that.  Sound effects fit weapons and whatnot.  It could use more attention to vehicles and sounds but overall still good.Quests:The quests are your run of the mill quests.  They are good and add to the the story.  They don't always feel quite at all like a grind.  Some can be, but that is normal it seems.  Other quests are more detailed.  I will say there are some bad bugs with some of the quests that require a npc to follow you.  That npc is prone to get stuck at a tree or rock and unlike the mercs that you hire, the quest npcs don't reappear at your side if you move too far away.  I have found that if you have a quest npc with you, if you bring out a vehicle and get in it, the npc will rellocate to your vehicle which is an unintended fix.  This leads to problems early game especially when you are travelling long distances.  When you have quest npcs with you, you can't fast travel.  If they get unexpectedly stuck in a tree you have to travel all the way back to retreive them.  This can be frustrating. There are some quests that you receive early in the game that won't be completed until later.  Many have had problems with this.  I imagine it will be fixed in later versions given this game is only early access.  SOme quests are a little buggy but that is mostly due to the fact that npcs end up getting stuck in random places.  There was one quest involving two npcs and I couldn't complete the quest because one of the npcs randomly got stuck in a mountain side and I couldn't get him down until I dug out the mountain side.Building:The game contains a lot of building which is great.  Kind of like minecraft.  You can make your own weapons and vehicles and whatnot.  You require schematics to build things and sometimes require to build one thing in order to build another.  It doesn't get overly complicated though.  The difficulty of the build is often representative of the usefulness of what you are building.  For instance, you can't just easily build a helicopter.  It requires you build a cockpick, rotors, engines, energy cells, etc.  It is a very intuitive building system that takes a little time to get use to but once you are it is very easy to use.  There is a lot of fun to be had.  A lot of creativity that can be used.  I will say the game could do better at helping you understand the proper needs of a vehicle.  I made a dune-buggy type car and I had all the pieces but in game I got this red text at the bottom that told me the car is overpowered or something.  It never really told me why it was overpowered or how to fix it.  The car still worked fine as it was.  Enemies: There are a lot of animals and enemies in the game.  Many of the animals are docile until you attack them which is nice.  Some of the animals are hostile from the start and it is fun and interesting to see which animals will attack on site and which animals will run right beside you.  The enemies are dangerous too.  Some prefer to sit back and snipe you.  Others will come slinging swords and whatnot.  Some will even mount turrets and will sling rockets and bullets at your face.  The animals and enemies come in all shapes and sizes and the size of the mob usually indicates how dangerous they are.  There are a few points where you fight some extremely large enemies and they can prove quite hard to defeat.  I will say the ranged mobs seem a lot more easy to conquer given they can be dodged easily.  Overall: Wonderful game with a ton of potential.  It already has a great deal built into and most of what will probably come from later versions is just more content.  I hope they fix some of the not-so-obvious bugs mentioned above (I am sure they will).  Creating your own camp and playing tower defense was really fun.  Being able to craft cars and helicopters and then drive them around was extremely fun.  The game does a great job easing you into the features and concepts of the game.  Very fun and leaves you wanting more (it is in alpha so that is to be expected).  I look forward to future updates and highly recommend you buying this game now if you enjoy rpg and open world sandbox games like terraria and minecraft.  There is a lot of replayability built into the game and right now about 20hrs worth of straight story line with some random quests thrown in.  It is a very balanced game.

Early Access Review
								(Early Access Review) Already a really fun game, and will be even better upon release. Very similar UI/ feel of an old MMO like "asherons call" but huge, singleplayer (multi fully does exist, I have not tried), with mining, crafting, hunting, and a great building system for vehicles and equipment. It even has a colony building and management system! Visually not bad at all, not amazing, but it is always improving and sometimes when the light catches trees or a vista correctly I still catch myself amazed by the world and its beauty. All of this is the foundation on a fun and interesting world, with decent missions and NPC writing, and a very imaginative and diverse ecosystem of wacky alien flora and fauna.
